I will definitely come back every now and then to have my kids learn and play around with some of the many activities they have. Also, the staff is super friendly. I would 1000% recommend. Some of the animals they have, and that the kids can interact with are chickens, lizards,shark, owls,and others. They also have a bunch of activities for toddlers, like a sandpit, tables for drawing and some toys."},{"author":"Michelle S.","datePublished":"2021-11-18","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Such a hidden little gem in our city. They offer fun events and also believe they do water rentals for the lagoon. A fun local way to explore with kiddos for a couple hours."},{"author":"Gennifer V.","datePublished":"2022-06-20","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Nice spot to learn about the lagoon history and other local flora and fauna facts. You can easily spend a few hours there with little ones."},{"author":"Liz M.","datePublished":"2021-10-12","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Lovely little local gem - perfect place for the kiddies to explore with hands-on interaction with cute reptiles and closeup views of beautiful birds. Highly recommend checking out this educational and interactive discovery center!"},{"author":"Grace C.","datePublished":"2021-05-24","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Stopped by during our vacation. 
There's various animals (i.e. tortoises, guinea pig, gecko, snakes, the bearded dragon, birds, starfish, horn shark, falcons, owls, hamster, bee observatory) you can see and some to touch too. You can  also pay for some veggies to feed the tortoise. There's a nature trail to walk on, sand trays to play in and dig for prehistoric animal teeth, scavenger hunt, fairy houses to look at, a play section, and other exhibits. There is complimentary hot chocolate and  coffee and restrooms inside."},{"author":"Ahyin E.","datePublished":"2022-08-12","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"If you just want your kid to be entertained seeing and touching a little bit animals. It is an amazing program!"},{"author":"Kristen M.","datePublished":"2019-06-20","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I found RWL on yelp looking for a reading tutor for my son. I came across Dr. Bloch. 

My son was 10 and had been in tutoring since first grade and was still testing at a 1st grade GLE. I was very frustrated that normal tutoring and learning were not working. My son would come home so disappointed in himself and not wanting to go to school. He had continued to be able to succeed overall in school as most studies were oral or done in group, so individual reading was not a dependency. However, the transition from 5th grade into middle school, I knew he would not be successful if we did not take drastic measures. 

I went through the assessment process with Dr. Bloch. He was able to diagnose areas where my son has physical limitations and his eyes were not tracking words correctly or able to focus as quickly as he should have been. 

I was excited to hear he had helped so many others, so we signed up for the program. At the first session, he was tested to get a base line on his reading level. Then the real work started. Each session thereafter, we performed drills that were designed to teach reading in a completely different method that what my son had been taught in school.

Within the first 4 sessions, my sons confidence had excelled. He was becoming a better reader. By the time the first month passed, we had completed only 7 sessions, but my son was already at 3rd grade levels tested at the school and had received increase scores on his quizzes for language arts.

When we started the program, my son struggled with reading across the board:
1) no interest
2) trouble identifying the words
3) slow reader
4) loss of focus
you name it, he struggled with it.

We are still in the program, but happy to say that he has now tested at almost grade level, which in only 3 short months was able to accomplish what years of tutoring could not.

So if you ask me should you consider this program, absolutely. I would do it again and have already booked future appointments to ensure that my son continues his success.

Thanks Dr. Bloch, we have really appreciated all that you have done for our son!!!"},{"author":"Rebekah H.","datePublished":"2018-08-01","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"My daughter is about to go into fifth grade and has struggled with reading since kindergarten. She always made progress, but the progress was much slower than it should have been - causing her to lag behind several grade levels in reading. Reading has been a chore for her that usually quickly ended in grumbling, whining, or tears. She has worn glasses for years as well, but not until we met with Dr. Bloch, did we realize that her eyes were not tracking properly and they were simply weak. 

 We decided to dedicate this summer to Reading Without Limits, and have just completed two months of the program. My daughter has gone from a first grade reading level, where she was never able to read longer than ten minutes without feeling tension in her head and eyes, to being almost on grade level and reading for over an hour at a time with no strain. She no longer feels tired when she reads, her reading speeds have more than doubled, and she is tracking the words much better. Her confidence has grown tremendously, and she now reads every night before bed because she wants to! We still have a month of the program left, and I am excited to see how much more progress she will make. 

 Dr. Bloch has given her the tools she needed to organize word parts in her mind and the tools she needed to strengthen the muscles in her eyes. I would definitely recommend meeting with Dr. Bloch if your child has struggled with reading. We are most grateful for this program and the research Dr. Bloch has done. I now have a reader on my hands and have literally made two trips to the library this week because she is devouring the books so quickly and WANTS more to read!! The program requires dedication from the child and the parents, but the results have been amazing!"},{"author":"Jk B.","datePublished":"2019-12-04","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"My daughter, who is currently in 5th grade and going to private school, was diagnosed with dyslexia in the second grade. We were referred to Dr. Bloch through the public school system's Independent Educational Program (IEP) in the spring of 2019, my daughter started with Dr. Bloch's "Reading With Out Limits" program about 3 months ago.  I can't begin to tell you the incredible reading results that my daughter has achieved under the supervision and training provided by Dr. Bloch through his amazing reading program. {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"The Clubhouse Social Skills Center For Children","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/SdNKC94nDwWYKwLcLO0USg/l.jpg","telephone":"(760) 683-5359","address":{"streetAddress":"6832 Embarcadero Ln","addressLocality":"Carlsbad","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"CA","postalCode":"92011"},"review":[{"author":"Timothy V.","datePublished":"2015-10-24","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Anna is absolutely amazing! Our son has been coming here for a couple of months now, and has been working on his interpersonal and social skills through the PEERS program, as well as continuing that training in the less formal LEGO club.

Each program is designed to aid children who need assistance in developing and growing their social skills, and our son has been making leaps and bounds since starting here! Our son has Asperger's syndrome, and Anna has been wonderful in working with him. We did all of our homework, and her credentials all check out (which is something that we always do before working with a service provider.)

Both of our boys come for LEGO club, and both of them look forward to it each week, even though we get up fairly early each Saturday to get there. LEGO club proved to be an excellent starting point for the boys, and allowed them to really grow comfortable in the setting before we got the PEERS program set up for our eldest. 

Now, to the details: the facility is absolutely beautiful. Build inside a dual use location in Carlsbad, the downstairs is set up for the program. Tastefully decorated, it is fun, light, and airy, with plenty of slightly subdued colors that look delightful without being overwhelming. There are plenty of toys, and the collection of LEGO's is constantly expanding. There is a good mix of special needs and typical children, which allows for real interactions that are all supervised and directed by Anna and her staff. Everyone is incredibly friendly, welcoming, and accepting. We truly could not be happier!

Would I recommend her to family and friends? Absolutely, and have already gone out of my way to do so. If you have a child that is struggling with social interactions, if you have a child who needs a boost, if you have a child who just doesn't quite get it, this is the place to go. We have already seen honest-to-goodness measurable improvements (which as an aside is something that is also done through the PEERS program.)

In summary, this program is excellent and Anna makes it all seem so easy. And, if I'm honest, I've probably picked up a pointer or two for applying in my own life as well."},{"author":"Mooki H.","datePublished":"2017-11-05","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"My child participated in Ana's summer camp for two summers.  The camp counselors all have higher education and training in child development and social skill coaching. {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Dallas Comedy Club","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Ow2KjZ42xPRsc1eHVRHP2w/l.jpg","priceRange":"Inexpensive","telephone":"(214) 814-1980","address":{"streetAddress":"3036 Elm St","addressLocality":"Dallas","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"TX","postalCode":"75226"},"review":[{"author":"Lincoln G.","datePublished":"2022-07-22","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I love love love this place. If the management sees this please let the performers be themselves free range, it's 2022 get it together."},{"author":"Steven H.","datePublished":"2022-07-18","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":2},"description":"For a comedy club, it doesn't seem like this place can take a joke. Very upset with this venue and their lack of communication and customer service."},{"author":"Dulse V.","datePublished":"2022-05-16","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Very fun experience, really small venue. Everyone had a fun vibe and they have virgin drink options for those who are pregnant and still want to feel included."},{"author":"Hannah P.","datePublished":"2021-11-10","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"If you are in the Deep Ellum area for the weekend or honestly anywhere in Dallas, you MUST stop at the Dallas Comedy Club. We had some drinks at the nearby bars (highly recommend Whiskey Hatchet) as well, and then walked here. We were blown away and it was the perfect end to our Saturday night. Great for date night or with a group."},{"author":"Fox E.","datePublished":"2018-02-01","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Not to be confused with the other DCH (Dat C*ck Hard) which probably happens to you fairly often if you check out the pix I post.

There's a lot of funny things about Dallas such as the assertion that it is a cooler or more exciting place to live or visit then Houston. But on its own merits there are some great things about Dallas and one of them is the life and heart and soul of this neighborhood. Deep Ellum.

One of the standouts is this Dallas comedy house where I recently got dragged to a performance and was surprised how much I enjoyed it in particular the excellent intimate and well-designed venue.

It'd be better if Jamie T featured here."},{"author":"Lyn J.","datePublished":"2019-09-11","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I enjoyed my time here. It is actually the first place I've been to in Downtown Dallas since moving to Texas. The building is spacious inside with many different rooms holding different events. Stand up open mic in one (free admission on Tues when I went), improvisation in another, classes, etc. They have a bar and a nice outdoor patio just off of it. Nice fun photos that adorn the halls as you walk down the aisles, and the staff are uber friendly. I wouldn't hesitate to go here again for an evening out."},{"author":"Frank J.","datePublished":"2019-12-22","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I attended the date night improv and had my expectations exceeded. The comedians were hilarious and the acting was super smooth. I haven't laughed that hard ever at a local comedy show but I'd for sure recommend this location to anyone looking for a good laugh. The food and drinks are also not super expensive and there was no drink requirement which was very nice and surprising. The jokes were also much more thoughtful and funny rather than simply resorting to racism to get some cheap laughs (I'm looking at you Lol Comedy)"},{"author":"Aaliyah W.","datePublished":"2018-01-24","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"I was able to venture (45 min drive might I add) to the Dallas Comedy House last night to meet up w/a group from MeetUp. The 1st thing that I would suggest people prepare for is parking, if there are other events going on in the area. Although I didn't have an issue finding a spot (I parked a 3 min walk away). Upon entering you walk up to a podium & present your ID & get a stamp on your hand. To the left is the bar area then to the right is a doorway that leads to the bathrooms & the 2 comedy rooms. The 1st room is for stand-up, the 2nd is for Improv. We went into the Improv room, which had a stage & some high & low tables for seating. The setting was quite small & intimate for the most part. Now for the show, it was decent. I have never been to an improv show so I didn't know what to expect. The 1st half, people went up in groups by levels; the 2nd half people were numbered off into 5 groups. I did have quite a few laughs but it was easy to see who has been doing it for a while & who hasn't. 

I did also try some popcorn & a shot of "WOO-IE CK*", whatever the heck thats suppose to be. The shot hit the spot though that's for sure. Furthermore, would I return? Yes, only if it was for a group meet up w/friends. I wasn't as so intrigued that I would drive 45 mins again."},{"author":"Kathleen W.","datePublished":"2019-09-02","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"I give 3 stars bc we came here for Labor Day brunch, which I recognize is not what the Dallas Comedy House is known for, and I also recognize that today was their first day serving brunch. I get it, and with all of those caveats, it really wasn't that bad. The service was friendly esp bc it's mainly bar service. The food was fine, small portions and a bit overpriced, overall a disappointment. BUT again, I recognize this is not what you come to the comedy house for, we just had slim pickins on Labor Day for brunch so I appreciate them being open today at all. Overall their new location seems really nice with an outdoor patio and everything, and I'd be willing to come back for a show one of these nights."},{"author":"Ellen F.","datePublished":"2019-09-29","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I couldn't have imagined a better place than DCH to be in my life. If you're looking for a great night out, with delicious food (it's not bar food - it's actually really great food) DCH is your place. If you want to be a part of the comedy community, DCH is your place. If you want a place to sit on a patio and have a beer or a burger or fries, DCH is your place."},{"author":"Allison K.","datePublished":"2019-09-29","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This. Food. Is. Amazing. 

Found our new brunch place!!

We brought our family here and all enjoyed our food a lot. Would for sure recommend the brunch fries and the sausage biscuits and gravy!! So delicious!"},{"author":"Marcela V.","datePublished":"2017-03-12","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I came for my first visit to the DCH during a weekend visit to Dallas, and I absolutely can't wait to go back! 

I watched the 90's memories show, and t brought back some good, far away wishes for reliving the 90's--punk fashion and all. 

The location is right in the Deep Ellen neighborhood, and just a quick lyft ride from great restaurants in the area. However, DCH also has food which was reasonably priced and looked good! They have a bar when you walk in + there are servers that will take your drink order or food order during the show. The space is small but it makes you feel that much more involved with the show. Its a little chilly inside, so be warned and bring a jacket!

We had so much fun watching the talented troop perform that night and they looked like they were having so much fun!! Come here for a different type of date night and really get to enjoy the local cultural side of Dallas!"},{"author":"Kent S.","datePublished":"2019-12-29","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"I came to see an improv show while visiting during the holidays. The audience and comedians were not diverse at all and the talent levels of the comedians vary quite a bit. The price of the tickets were extremely cheap at $10 and the food was actually decent. A decent bang for your buck if your looking for a cheap date option."},{"author":"Ricardo W.","datePublished":"2020-02-23","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Great place with great opportunities to excel in comedy with a fun group of people. {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Dallas International School","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/fG_xscTpIiWYNa6ji1n13w/l.jpg","telephone":"(469) 250-0001","address":{"streetAddress":"17811 Waterview Pkwy","addressLocality":"Dallas","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"TX","postalCode":"75252"},"review":[{"author":"Alexandre M.","datePublished":"2022-06-06","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Horrible school, i was there from K-8 and I understand that I was a less then ideal student. I go in for after school activities and the school campus is wonderful and modern"},{"author":"Tom G.","datePublished":"2017-10-19","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"With extreme nationalism running rampant, Dallas International School is a breath of fresh air. A dedicated and well-trained international staff helps educate and nurture true global citizens. We've been sending our daughter to DIS since Maternelle 1 (pre-school). We lived in California for a few years and found a similar school that she was able to jump right into. We are back in Dallas and at DIS and my 6th grader is fluent in English and French, speaks a little Spanish, and is now learning Mandarin. Not only does the school offer challenging curriculum but it expands minds and helps kids see other viewpoints. The student body is as close knit and supportive as you can get with tweens and teens. My daughter's future is bright and her options are boundless thanks to the Dallas International School."},{"author":"Ilene J.","datePublished":"2015-08-21","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Wow, what a difference a new administration can make. Yep, I wrote a negative review 4 years ago and we left for the exact reasons that were expressed in that review. 

But now we have decided to return to Dallas International School. 

Why? Because it is the only school in Dallas:Fort Worth that truly offers an exciting learning environment, an international education and the opportunity to meet people from around the world. It also offers the best IB (international baccalaureate programme) in the area. 

These are the reasons why we came to Dallas International School in the first place, and spent 9 years there before leaving disappointed with the previous administration. 

After hearing that things have changed, that there is a terrific headmaster, that the school is organized, that the faculty is highly educated and supportive, we have decided to give it another go. The newer facility is also very nice as well. 

So far, I can say that we are very impressed with all the upgrades. Now I can say: great concept, great implementation."},{"author":"Brent B.","datePublished":"2016-06-28","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Beware.  As another reviewer aptly points out " All in all, the school is primarily focused on the French students and the French culture, and makes a poor attempt at being an International school."

After relocating to Dallas from Washington State with a freshman high schooler achieving a 4.0 through Junior high, including pre=AP, we had high hopes for college prep that was promised in a private school education experience expanding her multi-lingual capabilities in an IB program.  

I could go on an on about the horrific experience at DIS (high school IB program) , but will sum it up here in bullet points:
- the headmaster considers himself a "CEO" as in 'running a business'.  This mindset is pervasive and reflected in the teachers he hires - few have the child's best interest at heart, they rarely make themselves available for after / during school hours access and all have second jobs or other outside priorities.
- the teacher turnover is virtually 100% in all subjects.  They all have second jobs or other higher priority interests.  A typical example are teachers that are there to get cost offsets for their own children.  Very few (if any) have IB training or experience.  Good luck trying to help your child navigate the syllabus, as often there isn't one because the teachers are winging it.  The headmaster seems to value teacher education levels (e.g. PhD) over and above any high school or educational teaching experience.  Just imagine your child having to deal with turnover in some of the more challenging subjects, such as 3 Economics teachers, 2 Biology teachers and 3 chemistry teachers in a three year time span.  The headmaster is bad enough, but the teachers are totally disengaged and often firing DIS and leaving, even mid year it was so bad.  And new hires (with other jobs, priorities) ended up making the children attend school from 8:30 to 5:00 pm to accommodate a teachers outside activities!
- No AP, SAT, ACT prep - None.  there was some feeble attempt at AP prep, but was made clear by the headmaster that this was not a priority (despite parent demands to incorporate into the curriculum).  
- Outside tutors required.  Because the teaching experience is so bad, you had better budget for outside tutors if you are striving for better than a C average grade for your child.  Same for AP prep, SAT and/or ACT prep.

Unless you are a French Ex-Pat looking for a school to help educate your child for assimilation back into a Euro educational system, you are wasting your time and money and RISKING your child's future by going to this school (at least at the high school level).

If your child plans to attend a US college and you want them to be well prepared for college life and have the best chance of getting into the college of their choice - this is NOT the high school for your family.  If you want a private education, there are FAR better choices.  Public Schools in Plano are head and shoulders above this place.

Bottom Line: Educational Malpractice is how I would sum up DIS High School's IB Program."},{"author":"DD S.","datePublished":"2015-02-19","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"We came from a sister school in Washington (FASPS), and as much as we liked that school, we like DIS better. Much more laid back, and the other parents are nowhere near as snooty as they were in WA."},{"author":"ernie c.","datePublished":"2012-11-19","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"The Dallas Int'l School offers an amazing experience where our children have flourished the last 5 years.  Like many Dallas families, we only speak English our in home.  

We wanted our girls to have a much broader experience - to learn to think with 'all their brain' and receive all the benefits the research has proven that an early, multilingual education brings to a child.  DIS is all that, and more.

Teachers are highly committed, parents involved, small classroom size and very well-behaved kids.  

There are parents that will be unhappy no matter where their kids go (that's just how they are). 

For parents that embrace the merits of a multilingual, multicultural environment - and want their kids to get an OUTSTANDING education in the process - should check out DIS.   

And ask about recent national test scores, the colleges the recent graduating class attended, their scholarship amounts, etc.....  It's a tremendous educational value."},{"author":"Mrs D.","datePublished":"2012-08-24","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"So far there has been only one, very one-sided review from a parent with a child for whom the school was not a good fit.

Not all schools fit all children.

It is true DIS is academically challenging. The French system is much more challenging, in terms of content and in terms of intellectual rigor, than the American system. 

So if you have an academically challenged child,  or a child who really isn't interested much in learning, then this is definitely not the school for you.  

If you have a child who struggled to learn English as a first language, then this school is definitely not for you.  Children take not only French, but Spanish, and at 6th grade can take Mandarin Chinese.  So from age 3, all children are working in 3 languages.

It is not true, as stated another review, that the focus is primarily on French.  In the early grades,the school is 40% English, 40% French and about 20% Spanish.  The ratio slowly switches as children get older, such that there is majority French instruction by Middle School, but there is still a substantial amount of English (it's probably 60 to 65%  instruction in French by the Middle School level).  BUT this just means the content is taught in French; it doesn't mean they are learning French all of that time  (they are already pretty fluent by then).  They are doing math, biology, physics, computer science, history,  geography, etc. and they do many of these subjects in both English and French.

I have two children at the school, one in Middle and one in Elementary school, and both started at age 3.  I have never hired tutors, and there is alot of homework starting in about 3rd grade.  There is homework help at the school for French, for those children who don't have anyone at home who speaks French. 

Most DIS kids are fairly fluent by the 4th grade or so, so they don't necessarily need help with language beyond that point.

There are teachers at the school who tutor if you need it (I think it's sort of reasonable to expect that if a child is learning a language and no one at home speaks it,you might need some outside help now and then).

My experience with the French teachers has also been nothing but positive.  The French teachers are excellent.  They are recruited from among teachers in France, where teaching is a competitive profession, where it's actually rather difficult to become a teacher, and where teacher training is much more extensive than in the US.

I know some people sometimes perceive that the English instruction is sometimes not as strong as the French instruction, but what can I say, the American system academically just isn't as strong, so when you have the two side by side, it shows.

Does that mean the English teachers are not good?  No, it means the French educational system is stronger than the American one, and that, it seems to me, is an argument for putting your child in this school.

My children have excelled at the school. My son scores above the 95th percentile on American standardized tests.

I know other parents of children who started at age 3 and went up through MIddle or High school who have the same experience.  I also know that  one of the DIS graduating Seniors last year got a President's Scholarship at SMU this year, and that is the most prestigious scholarship the school gives.   Given that it was a small graduating class, that is quite impressive.

Other DIS graduates have gone on to other universities and earned the equivalent of a year of credit based on their IB scores; in many cases, they have gone right into upper-level courses, and this is especially true in languages.  Some children have gone to universities in Canada, where tuition is much lower than in the US, and where DIS students are more competitive than most American students.

As I said, this is clearly a school for academically-oriented children and families.  If you want your child to go to college on an athletic scholarship, you probably ought to look elsewhere, but if you want a child who comes out at 12th grade with a better education than most college-educated Americans have, this is probably the place for you."},{"author":"Scott N.","datePublished":"2015-06-12","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I happened upon the below review by accident and felt compelled to respond.  Let me start by saying that my son has been attending DIS for two years.  He is now in first grade.  The below reviewer neglects to mention whether her review is based on a personal experience with the school or based upon feedback she has heard from others.  My review is based on my first-hand observations..  

At the outset, the assertion that communication is "non-existent" is untrue.  I have a daughter at Parish Episcopal, and I can say without reservation, that DIS does a better job of keeping me informed.  I receive multiple communications DAILY from staff and teachers at DIS.  Teachers will regularly update us on daily classroom activities, which sometimes include pictures of the children performing the activities being described.  Frankly, I love being at my computer at work and receiving a picture of what my child is doing at that very moment.  I've never had a school do that before.  The assertion that communication is "non-existent" is simply false.  

The comment that there is "some anti-American sentiment" is equally untrue.  I am a gun toting, conservative Texan and a staunch supporter of our American military, and I assure you that if I EVER sensed any anti-American sentiment, I would whip my boy out of that school so fast that it would make your head spin.  I love this country, and I would never tolerate anything "anti-American" and surely would never voluntarily expose my boy to it.  

The reviewer further asserts that "there are issues concerning the education of the non-French speakers".  I don't know what she means, but I don't speak French, and my boy didn't speak French before attending.  He is doing great, and his studies are on par with his similarly aged cousins, except that my boy is fluent in French.  And the school does offer a summer introductory course.  

The "social issues" analysis is ridiculous and shameful.  DIS has a zero tolerance rule regarding physical contact.  They are actually very strict.  The fact is that these children are very closely monitored and loved.  Today was my son's last day of school for the year, and the teachers and assistants were very emotional - some were weeping.  My boy actually says that he "loves" his teacher and her assistant.  I cannot recount the number of occasions that my boy was ill or was struggling with something, only to be comforted by a school staff member or teacher.  My wife and I regularly express to each other how fortunate we were to have him surrounded by people that love him.  The assertion that the teachers don't "nurture" is categorically, unequivocally false, and it saddens me that someone would characterize them in that manner.  These are simply wonderful people that love what they do.

As for the school's responsiveness, once again, I cannot give them higher praise.  The school and staff are extremely responsive. 

As for the curriculum, my boy is only in first grade, so I don't have first-hand experience, but I do know that SMU awarded the President's Scholarship to a recent graduate of DIS.  Here is how SMU describes the recipient of this award:

"The President's Scholars Program is awarded to students who have shown exemplary academic and leadership skills. The award provides full tuition and fees as well as study abroad. Students who live on campus also receive a scholarship for room and board. For consideration for the President's Scholarships, the highest academic awards given by the University, students must have exceptional achievement on the SAT or ACT and in their high school curriculum."

The President's Scholarship is awarded to only 20-25 freshmen.  So, not only did this DIS graduate gain admission to SMU, but he also had what it took to procure a scholarship that was awarded to only 22 of its entering freshmen.  

Suffice to say, I am 100% satisfied with from I have experienced with this school so far.  The high school students I have met seem incredibly well adjusted and talented.  It is simply a wonderful academic institution."},{"author":"A. M.","datePublished":"2011-07-05","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"I went to this school for years before I finally ended leaving. Though the lower school was okay, the upper level teachers are abusive and have no compassion for their students or the subjects they teach. The school does have issues with physical abuse. Slapping, kicking, and punching are regular on the playground. Most of the teachers are washed up french teachers who could not get better jobs with their foreign degrees. Therefore, they seem to harbor ill feelings toward the school and with it, the students. The administration turns a blind eye to abuse from the teachers. A teacher who continuously verbally and physically abused enjoyed employment at D.I.S for over ten years despite parental complaints. Instead of firing the teacher, parents were pressured to move their students elsewhere ( Three during my time at the school).   

As for the psychological effects on the students, most of my peers who stayed ended up socially awkward. I currently work with some current students from D.I.S. At even their young ages, I can see the crippling effects of the school. 

Academically,The French-centric nature of the school can cause problems in later years. Students leave D.I.S with limited, if any, knowledge of American History or tradition. I strongly suggest a traditional private or public school. If the bi-lingual track is a must for your child, consider sending them for their formative language years. No child should stay at the school past 3rd grade. Consider talking to students who have experienced both D.I.S and another school."},{"author":"Tish T.","datePublished":"2015-04-16","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"DIS is an international school that gives children and parents seeking a worldly point of view.  Our kids have been there since 3 years old and have had a great experience.  So much so that they will not even consider going to another school.  There are many teachers who tutor privately."},{"author":"Rhea S.","datePublished":"2011-12-20","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I think it's important to provide some balance to the only review on Yelp about DIS, as it appears to have been written by someone with an axe to grind and in no way represents our experience nor the experience of the many friends we've made there. It also cites an incorrect address for the primary school--it's actually 6039 Churchill Way.

My wife and I weren't entirely comfortable with the idea of sending our kids to a private school, but we loved our neighborhood and the public school options were unfortunately seriously deficient. We didn't want to move to the burbs, so we went looking for a private school in Dallas that would teach our children (as we do) that there are more important things in the world than amassing and displaying wealth, which turned out to be a really difficult proposition. However, we found exactly what we were looking for at DIS. We have two sons, 6 and 3 years old--our older son is in his 3rd year at DIS and our 3 year old just started this year. We've been overjoyed with the education they're receiving and with the friends from all over the world that all of us have made through the school. It's amazing to hear our older son helping his little brother with French pronunciation and teaching him how to count in French. We've actually been inspired to get Rosetta Stone for French as a Christmas gift for each other so we can keep up with them as they start to speak (and perhaps conspire) with each other more and more in a foreign language. Everyone at the school has taken a genuine personal interest in our children's development. Amazingly, one of the teaching assistants who moved to California when her husband transferred jobs still emails us regularly to check on our younger son's progress since he had a bit of a challenge starting school so young (at 3 years and 2 months). Thanks to her help and the attention of his teachers and other teaching assistants, not to mention all the friends he's made, he now looks forward to school and it's sometimes difficult to extract him at the end of the day.

Since my wife and I both work full-time, we were especially gratified that DIS offers excellent after school care until 6 pm, with great activities for the kids. Our boys have been exposed to karate, yoga, circus (taught by ex-Cirque de Soleil performers!), gymnastics, soccer, and drama, with the opportunities only continuing to expand as they get older. And, for what we would argue is a much more interesting education, the price at DIS is still significantly less than most other Dallas private schools. If you're looking for a school with a great football team and lots of Bentleys in carpool line, this is not the place for you. If you want your children to be in a challenging yet nurturing environment that prepares them to value and understand the world outside of the provincial Dallas establishment, DIS is a great choice."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":4,"reviewCount":13}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"The Clifton School at Clifton","telephone":"(404) 636-4073","address":{"streetAddress":"1700 Clifton Rd NE","addressLocality":"Atlanta","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"GA","postalCode":"30329"},"review":[{"author":"Gi G.","datePublished":"2014-07-29","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"As of the writing of this review, there is no listing for The Clifton School at Clairmont.  I didn't realize how good Clifton School was for my son until I moved to another state.  Clifton School is truly a one-of-a-kind experience.
Things I loved:
1)Smaller class sizes- My son was first in one of the infant classrooms and then transitioned to a toddler classroom.  There were about 8 kids per one AM or PM teacher and an additional assistant.
2)Reggio Emilia approach to teaching- You can check out a better definition on Wikipedia.  
-Basically, the approach believes in discovery learning through exploration and creativity.  Each child is allowed his or her own learning style.  Group learning is important too (my son at 20 months could say the names of his classmates).  There is a curriculum coordinator who goes classroom to classroom to see how the kids are learning.  At a point in the year, the coordinator/team calls you to let you know how your child is doing.  Also, there are sit down meetings with teachers.
-It's actually much bigger than just a way of learning.  The approach also believes in an open curriculum so that teachers can change plans based on children learning.  
-The physical environment is important too.  Reggio schools have open areas with piazzas.  Kids aren't just shuttled between a small classroom and an outdoor playground.  The infant classrooms, for example, are clustered together into a "village" with an open indoor gross motor play area called a piazza.  Each village has an outdoor play area as well.  This is very unique.  I've toured multiple daycares in Kentucky and most are not this open with natural lighting.  You might not think this is important but if you were in a small classroom day in an day out you would start feeling cramped too.
-The approach believes in parent involvement.  Clifton School has a PTA that meets on a regular basis and generates money through fundraising.  Each class has at least one class rep.  Parents for each classroom are put on an email list, so concerns can be addressed.  There are multiple ways in which you can submit concerns from the classroom to the administrative level.  This is unique too.  Again, multiple daycares in Georgia and Kentucky DO NOT allow this level of parent involvement (eg kindercare, primrose, clarian place).
3)Great use of resources
-Each classroom has a digital camera.  The teachers take pictures of the kids during the day and write a small one slide powerpoint that goes out to the parents' email list.  You really feel connected to what the kids are doing that day.  It gave me a smile at the end of my day to see an email with a picture of my son playing a drum.  I used to send the email attachments to grandparents to let them know how my little one was doing.
-The Clairmont Campus now has access to fresh fruits and vegetables from a local farm.  Parents place orders and pick up their produce at the Clairmont location.  This is a great sustainable living initiative.
-They hire real photographers from the community to come take pictures of kids for class picture day.  They have a music teacher who sits down with individual classes.  My son got to see someone play a harpsichord when he was 18 months old.
4)Great teachers- great education backgrounds and they love the kids.  When my son was about to move, tears were shed by teachers and administration.  I really felt like I lost a second family.

What I didn't like:
1)It's been mentioned on Google Reviews that the administration isn't responsive to parent concerns.  I did have an issue with the closure-due-to weather policy and didn't get feedback.  I'm not a pushy parent and ended up not caring.  The truth is that there are multiple ways to communicate with the administration, unlike other day cares.  If I were pushy enough, I could've brought it up at a PTA meeting.  I remember the parents got upset that the teachers were only sending out daily word ppts instead of ppts with pictures, and someone posted a complaint to the parent email listserv.  The problem was resolved that week.  
2)Clifton School is only open to Emory and CDC employees.  I'm not entirely sure of all the reasons for this but it's really not fair to keep this great school confined to a small group of people.  Clifton School will now be receiving a Georgia lottery funded pre-K and enrollment has to be open to the community.  Maybe this will change their opinions.  
3)The price!  This school is expensive and I'd like to believe it's worth it.  The school grounds, technologies, and equipment are really kept up nicely.  Parents of infants have Similac available as an optional part of the program.  We cut down on formula costs after the switch to Similac.
4)Long wait list- I applied in late Summer of 2012, delivered Sept 2012, and my son didn't come off the wait list until May 2013. 

Boy, I could write more but it looks like Yelp won't allow it.  I hope this gives a little more info than the angry reviews out there."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":5,"reviewCount":1}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Friends School of Atlanta","telephone":"(404) 373-8746","address":{"streetAddress":"862 Columbia Dr","addressLocality":"Decatur","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"GA","postalCode":"30030"},"review":[{"author":"Delia S.","datePublished":"2019-11-12","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"If you want your kids to be more than just smart, to be Great human beings, This is your place. The whole culture puts being caring, honest,  upfront, and respectful front and center. I see it in my kids every day. (ok, almost every day. They're still humans! :))
But they really do learn in a much more varied 'landscape' of people, of cultures, family structures and points of view and they are better for it. Plus they are getting all the tools for great conflict management skills, a key predictor of happiness. And that's the icing on the cake of solid academics. My kids are learning, and most importantly, they are happy and confident, they feel loved and like they "belong" at their school. 
(They beg me to stay at aftercare to play with their friends!)"},{"author":"Cecily T.","datePublished":"2019-11-07","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"When it came time to find a kindergarten for my son, I knew that I wanted a setting with small class sizes, skillful teachers, and a focus on academics. However, as a psychologist, I also knew that I wanted a school that had a focus on social-emotional development. I feel so lucky to have found the Friends School for my son. They sincerely practice what they preach. My son has ADHD, and the teachers were exceptional in identifying his needs, using targeted strategies to assist him, and communicating with me about ways to support him. Despite his challenges, they never lost sight of his unique strengths. Now that he is in first grade, he is thriving. And, the beauty of it is, because it's a small school, his current teachers already have some familiarity with him and have been able to give me great feedback about his improvement. 

The focus on ensuring that kids are well-rounded citizens is also a real asset for FSA. My son is courteous, kind, and socially aware. He talks about helping the homeless, eating healthy foods, and caring for the environment. He gets adequate exercise and sunlight during the school day (which research shows is linked to greater energy and concentration). He is learning conflict management skills, mindfulness, empathy, and how to be a good member of a team. As someone who works with business leaders, I know that these lessons will be invaluable in his life. I once told the headmaster that he radiates warmth. His demeanor is so kind, upbeat, and positive - he never looks like he's going through the motions. I believe that he sets a great tone for the rest of the school. I can't rave enough about FSA. I'm so lucky that we found it!"},{"author":"Pamela G.","datePublished":"2018-10-08","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"We decided to go to Friends because of the environment they've created. We wanted our child to not only learn the academics but also have a parallel set of values at school- that he is respected, that he respects others and his community, that kindness and compassion are equally, if not more, important and that participation in his community is a responsibility. He comes home talking about social justice, and equality and asking questions that I never had the chance to think about until college. 
Additionally, our son is excelling academically- in areas where he needed more challenge, they gave it to him. In areas where he needed more support, they gave it to him. He has great, big ideas and they allow for exploration and deep dive into topics that are of interest to the student."},{"author":"Jack R.","datePublished":"2012-06-08","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"What a great place to put your kid. It's a secular independent school that follows Quaker principles. I give Friends School a ton of credit for how well my kid has apparently turned out. Great student-teacher ratio, excellent teachers who really care about the children. The move to the Columbia Drive campus really kicked this place up a notch and the facilities are all first rate. The school's commitment to diversity is unmatched in Atlanta."},{"author":"Caitlin D.","datePublished":"2013-03-20","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"My son went to middle school here for three years. He came from a reputable public school. We generally weren't worried about him academically, but boy were we impressed with the way FSA teachers challenged him, made him think, and allowed him to take the time to REALLY learn about topics that interested him.

FSA doesn't stress tests, especially not standardized tests. High-stakes standardized testing was why I wanted him OUT of pubic schools. But I do find it interesting that the very school that did NOT stress over testing was the very one that made a real difference when he did finally take a standardized (although not a "high-stakes") test three years later.

FSA teachers are some of the most dedicated teachers there are--they take time to get to know each child individually, carefully construct lessons, and "kid-watch" to understand how to ensure that every individual child reaches his or her potential. The teachers are masters of their craft. They stay on top of professional learning and collaboratively work to construct challenging curricula. I cannot recommend this school enough!"}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":5,"reviewCount":5}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Child & Family Services of SE Alabama Inc Msw Lcsw","telephone":"(334) 793-2237","address":{"streetAddress":"100 Westside Dr","addressLocality":"Dothan","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"AL","postalCode":"36303"},"review":[{"author":"Mark L.","datePublished":"2021-03-23","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"We received a referral for speech therapy for our son back in September 2020, we contacted this office and they had us fill out initial paperwork and we're told someone would contact us soon. A couple weeks went by, we called to check in, no updates, someone would call us back soon. We kept this up for a little while, eventually they told us that it would be after Christmas. We heard good things about this place, so we extended our referral as it was soon to expire. After the New Year, we called again, two of their therapists we out on maternity leave, but they were expecting additional help soon, so it would now be February. Ok. Mid-February we called and left messages, no one ever calls us back, this happened several times. Here it is March is almost done and I finally get a hold of someone. They hope to be able to see our son by the summer. Done with this place. They have shown over time that they have poor customer (patient) service and only care about the money, otherwise they should have made it clear a long time ago that they didn't have the capacity to see our son. Stop dragging people along! Maternity leave happens, take hard look at your sustainability and if you truly care about patients, direct them elsewhere so they can receive the treatment they need. Have the basic decency to return a phone call in a reasonable amount of time, not weeks later if at all. Only two or three times did we leave a message and someone contacted us within a business day. {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Bethany Divinity College & Seminary","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/c1fezDa7Vz6CLktl77fZXA/l.jpg","telephone":"(334) 793-3189","address":{"streetAddress":"2573 Hodgesville Rd","addressLocality":"Dothan","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"AL","postalCode":"36301"},"review":[{"author":"Mutt J.","datePublished":"2016-02-29","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"If your degree is from a school that is not accredited from a recognized agency, it will be absolutely worthless.
If it seems to good to be true... it probably is!

See this yelp link:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/bethany-divinity-college-and-seminary-dothan


https://www.bethanybc.edu/information/accreditation.html

Accreditation Information....... 
---------------------------------------------
American Association for Higher Education and Accreditation

AAHEA
---- On May 24, 2013, Bethany Divinity College and Seminary, Inc., was granted Full Accredited Status with the American Association For Higher Education and Accreditation.


This association is bogus and is listed here as an unrecognized higher education accreditation organization:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unrecognized_higher_education_accreditation_organizations

There are also a number of specialized accredited agencies which are approved by both the Department of Education and CHEA. 
Some schools have both regional and specialized accreditation. If you select a school that only has specialized accreditation, 
be aware that your efforts may not be as accepted within academe. For better or worse, there are various levels of respect 
associated with the different accrediting agencies and the regional agencies are considered the standard. However, four 
relevant specialized agencies are:
1 Association for Biblical Higher Education (ABHE)
2 Association of Theological Schools in the United States and Canada (ATS)
3 Distance Education and Training Council (DETC)
4 Transnational Association of Christian Colleges and Schools (TRACS)

Look in the Christian Distance Learning Degree and Program Directory

It only lists accredited (U.S.) or government-approved (international) colleges, universities, and seminaries in the Christian Distance Learning Degree and Program Directory. 
(It does include some unaccredited private K-12 schools and programs geared toward homeschoolers, but that's a significantly different situation.) 
If the Christian school you're considering is not listed there, you have good reason to be cautious.
 
Bethany Divinity College and Seminary does NOT appear in the list of approved seminaries and colleges on Bakers Guide to Christian Online Learning:
http://www.bakersguide.com/directory/"}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":1,"reviewCount":1}}

Color Wheel exceeded all my expectations.  We would recommend it to anyone and look forward to returning again soon."},{"author":"kristin e.","datePublished":"2015-05-16","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I live in the City of Decatur and I would not send my children to any other after care center. {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Turning Sun School","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/XG7vADEGIzpCxOKe53kggA/l.jpg","telephone":"(404) 228-1797","address":{"streetAddress":"2500 Hosea L. Williams Dr Ne","addressLocality":"Atlanta","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"GA","postalCode":"30317"},"review":[{"author":"Maureen F.","datePublished":"2018-09-04","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Both my children attend this pre-school and the thing to keep in mind is that it's a pre-school, not a daycare. So while your child will have wonderfully enriching opportunities from highly trained reggio educators, they'll follow the school schedule. Not sure why it's  Decatur when they're in APS as are we, but we manage just fine. Both my husband and I work full and while the school day can be tricky and requires some supplemental care for pickup, our kids have an amazing progressive education full of play, freedom,creativity and love from their teachers, most of whom have been on staff for many years, in a highly inclusive inter-sectional environment and we love it!\n\nThey're EXTREMELY mindful of staffing ratios and ensuring kids have proper care, attention and oversight. So they encourage parents to keep their kids on a schedule as to when their kids can expect them."},{"author":"britton T.","datePublished":"2017-07-31","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"My son went to "summer sessions" two years in a row. He loved it so much the first time & asked all school year long when he could go back. We loved the location, staff, philosophy and the hours for the summer. They teach the kids to recycle, compost, garden & all of the other standard social stuff you get in preschool. Lots of outdoor time. They let the kids lead the learning, so if you are looking for a lot of structure- this is not the place for you. We were never late to pickup so I can't speak to the other review, but I never experienced any negative or aggressive people on staff. I trusted them to care for my child and they were good at reporting back to me at the end of each day."},{"author":"Kevin E.","datePublished":"2017-12-28","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"My child attends "full time".  The teachers are very good and I believe her level of learning and exploring out paces her previous local day care center.  I'm writing this review to point out a few items for prospective parents to consider before selecting TSS.  Food is not included with tuition, so packing lunches is a requirement.  They're strict about no peanuts, so no PB&J's at this school.  They're also fairly particular about monitoring how you prepare the food (slicing round things to avoid choking hazards, etc) and making sure it's nutritionally balanced.  We received some "coaching and counseling" (soft approach) on this topic.  Also, the hours for "full time" are 830am-330pm.  For working parents this can be tough since it does not coincide with conventional work hours.  There's no extended care option (currently) at the EL campus.  If you're a stay-at-home parent looking for some time to yourself, then this may work.  Also, you pay tuition for the month.  (Full disclosure, their calendar is published.)  We had wished we'd reviewed it more closely.  We feel we pay a lot in tuition while they seemed to be closed quite a bit or pop the random 130pm pick up for staff meeting.  I don't understand why they can't schedule their staff meetings after 330pm to avoid additional inconvenience to those paying for "full time" care.  As working parents we're often scrambling for supplemental care or taking lots of time off work to accommodate.  They don't pro-rate the tuition to reflect all the time they require early pick up or all the closed time they incorporate into the schedule.   The EL campus follows Decatur school's calendar, even though many of our older kids are on the APS schedule (Drew).  We have found ourselves with 1 child off for a break (spring/winter etc) 1 week and the TSS child off the next.  We're paying lots of $$$$ for camps, sitters etc to cover childcare while we work.  Also, they spend a lot of time outside in a muddy, dirt (not much mulch) play area...so we've thrown away lots of trashed kids clothes.  In summary, when they  ARE open....the learning opportunities and staff are good.  This is not the place to send your kid if you work full-time or have other kids in the APS school schedule.  It's roughtly twice as much per month as our old pre-school, provides no food, opens 2 hours later than our and closes 2.5 hours earlier than our other center, and is probably closed/closes early an average of 4 days per month more.  We can't wait until next year when our kiddo is in 4K."},{"author":"Delia S.","datePublished":"2016-11-13","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Pickup is at 1pm. If you pick up late, there is a $1 fee per minute. That is fine by me. So sometimes I was late and happily paid the fee. Then I got an odd phone call about it, reminding me of the fee. So i responded that I knew about the fee and was happy to pay it. (i am very direct). But I asked, are you hinting that i should not be late? Is it a problem? (I don't speak in code). The person said it was fine to be late as long as I paid. Later I found out from my child, he was being separated out from the "staff kids" and made to stay indoors with the teachers. While this first explained to me as a staffing issue, my kid was completely incorporating this into his self-image, and moping around saying he wasn't a staff kid, if he couldn't complete a challenging task. When I asked again about this, another staff person told me this was a deterrent. Not a punishment, but a deterrent. Look these words up, a deterrent IS a punishment, they were trying to deter ME from being late, by punishing my kid, instead of just telling me straight out! The administrator who told me this was aggressive in her body language and her tone, to the point where i actually sat down, to make myself small and relaxed to defuse what was becoming an ugly situation. This is unacceptable and has never happened to me in the business world.  Then to make things extra fun, they called my *EX husband to ask him for MY credit card number within minutes to get my payment for pulling my kid out. I believe that is illegal, let alone unethical. This place has an amazing philosophy, but some of its administrators are willing to let children be hurt, and are willing to raise their voices, over simple policy matters they could just be straight about. Also, they think being on time is a moral issue, while yelling is ok. It was not the place for our family."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":3.5,"reviewCount":4}}
