{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Rosa Parks Library & Museum","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/z5rwzIbR0-gnBl7B2M4UPQ/l.jpg","telephone":"(334) 241-8615","address":{"streetAddress":"252 Montgomery St","addressLocality":"Montgomery","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"AL","postalCode":"36104"},"review":[{"author":"Kathy C.","datePublished":"2022-09-17","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"A must see! The displays and videos were amazing. I learned so much & wish everyone could go here. First class museum!"},{"author":"Tank G.","datePublished":"2022-06-28","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"This Museum is located across from the Troy campus. It is co-located with a library that is only accesible to Troy students. They have metered street parking right out front and within a reasonable walking distance.

The site of the museum is significant because it is where Rosa Parks was arrested on a bus for not giving up her seat. It has a historical marker out front marking the location. It has a neat sculpture outside that can only be viewed directly, any other angles and you are looking at some posts in the group.  There is also a very nice sculpture of Ms. Parks sitting alone in her seat on the bus. It makes for great photos.

The museum is small and offers self guided tours. There are no pictures allowed in the main exhibit area. The tour begins in a small room with benches around it. You watch a movie about segregation in Montgomery, the bus system and the boycott. Once the movie is over, some doors open and leads you to the next area. The next area is a pretty neat reenactment of Rosa Parks being arrested on the bus. You view the action as if you are viewing it from outside of the bus. It is very nice and really makes you feel like you are in the action. 

 After the reenactment on the bus, some doors open up to a gallery that has exhibits, videos, artifacts, and pictures. You move at your own pace from this spot until the end of the tour. You will see a replica carpool vehicle over there, you will also hear stories told by people that were there during that time via videos and you will see a display of leaders riding the bus after the boycott ended. They give you the option of using your phone for an audio tour in a few sections of the museum. It provides you some information about what you are looking at. I did not use it because it seemed like more effort than what it was worth to me. Some type of push button audio kiosk would be perfect in its place. Anyway, as i mentioned, the exhibit area is not a very big area. We went through it in about 15 minutes.. The entire tour took us about 30 minutes. Even though thee is not a lot to it, it was still a nice visit and I  learned a bit. It does a good job making you feel as if you are back during that time.

No museum would be complete without a gift shop, this one is no exception. They have a small gift shop where you not only purchase you museum admission, but you can buy souvenirs like shirts or bags.

All-in-all this a decent museum. I love that it is located on the historical site where the bus incident occurred. It is small, but still makes a great impact. It' is definitely worth a visit if you are in downtown Montgomery. I would recommend checking out some of the other nearby museums, like the Legacy Museum and Civil Rights Center to maximize your trip."},{"author":"Penny S.","datePublished":"2022-04-18","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This museum is two parts - our family of five just did the museum experience. We had to wait for it to be go in as there are timed small experiences for the first part. This was really just an intro to welcome to the museum. 

We spent probably 1.5 hours here without doing the second portion. The last half of the museum has lots of reading, but the first part was a great simulation experience that even the youngest would get a deeper understanding of Rosa. The museum store could be improved as there are so many amazing kid books about Rosa Parks.

The library next door was mentioned as something to do - but they said this was only for school groups. Don't forget to walk several blocks to see the Rosa Parks statue at the fountain.

This is well worth the entrance fee!"},{"author":"Carrie G.","datePublished":"2022-05-09","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"The coolest thing is that this is on site of where Rosa parks bus stop was! In the museum I loved that we could watch the situation as a pedestrian looking into the bus. I love museum that's make things as real as possible! We really learned a lot here!"},{"author":"Endora B.","datePublished":"2022-03-06","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Always nice to know your history. If it had not been for her not giving up her seat on the bus no telling where we would be"},{"author":"Becky D.","datePublished":"2022-07-23","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I took my 8 yr old here to tour the Rosa Parks exhibit. The exhibit was educational & engaging. The staff at the library were also helpful including Marilyn, one of the custodians."},{"author":"Richard R.","datePublished":"2019-06-09","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Meet Mr. Rivets, the robotic operator of a time machine bus that looks very similar to the buses used by the City of Montgomery during the bus boycott of 1955-56.

    __V__
   |  ~  ~  |
   |   o o  |        Hi!!!
 {    [---]   }
   |______|

You will find him in the Children's Annex of the Rosa Parks museum which features a historic time-jump to different dates using large screens on either side of the time machine and prerecorded narrating. On the second floor is a photo timeline of Civil Rights events and informational columns highlighting the important faces of the movement and their story.

Back in the main building is a gift shop, exhibition art hall and a self guided tour highlighting the famous story of Rosa Louise McCauley Parks and her defiance to give up her seat on that faithful day. What I never knew about the history of this event was that it wasn't altogether random. Rosa Parks planned to do this with the help of other civil rights leaders so they could use it as a launching point for a federal case against the unconstitutional segregation laws in Alabama. It was only an idea, but Rosa fulfilled it when she found the opportunity, because it couldn't be staged. That takes nothing away from Rosa Parks. The danger of such defiance was deadly real, as witnessed by the Freedom Riders in the same era.

Oddly, the case was not brought to court using Rosa. Instead they used the first person to actually defy the bus laws, young Claudette Colvin, whom was 15 and pregnant at the age of her arrest. Her arrest happened on March 2nd, 1955, a full 9 months before Rosa's arrest on December 1, 1955.

The story is told using a full sized model of a Montgomery bus as you stand outside of the bus looking through the windows (which utilize TV screens). The bus is set in a room that looks like a small movie set with buildings, a faux street and streetlights. Here is a link to a Youtube video of this exhibit: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h82ajl69iy0

OVERALL it is a great experience, especially when coupled with the other Civil Rights museums in the downtown area. Not far away from the RP Library the City of Montgomery is working to construct a park and monument @ the site of the famous bus stop where Rosa boarded. Not sure when it will be ready as digging was underway during our May 2019 visit. The Library is actually the location of the arrest. Both the Time Machine exhibit in the Children's Annex and the Bus Arrest exhibit in the main building are must see's when visiting Montgomery Alabama and the Freedom Trail. Come see the quiet unspoken life's work of a Civil Rights pioneer.


2019/82"},{"author":"Ben E.","datePublished":"2022-01-08","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This place is really good. It was engaging, emotional, and it left me feeling so optimistic about our ability to make a positive impact. I recommend it for everyone. Another thing I liked, it's much more immersive than most museums. Def recommend."},{"author":"Pumpkin C.","datePublished":"2021-02-01","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Another great museum to visit while you're in Montgomery. I decided to take my family, luckily it wasn't packed during that time, which gave us the freedom to take our time to reflect while reading and listening to the host. They do not allow you to sit on the bus, however just to be there was an experience."},{"author":"Julio H.","datePublished":"2018-01-27","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Such a historical figure... 

This museum is a very fun museum. Your visit starts with a brief video, only to be followed by an interactive exhibit. It is one of the coolest things I remember at a museum. It really charges you emotionally and creates an interest. After the initial exposition, you follow into another room where you free flow and explore at will. If you are not familiar at all with the Civil Rights movement, well, there are lots of reading to do on these displays.

This is one of the better exhibits I have been to, and I truly think they should make it a traveling exhibit."},{"author":"Paisley T.","datePublished":"2016-06-24","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"Well, 2 out of 2 exhibits were 'out of order' and so I didn't get to see the museum like normal. But still. 

I guess the bus time machine would be cool for grade school kiddos. I mean, the video was informative and all but the shaky bus was just a goofy distraction for me as an adult. And since the Rosa Parks hologram wasn't working I cannot comment on the most critical piece of the museum: The actual part about Rosa and the boycott. Oh well. 

On the other side, the room opened up but they had to turn the lights on in order to see the graphics and pictures. I basically just walked through and read the placards. Towards the back, when you walk through the larger exhibit pieces and follow the boycott timeline that's where it gets cool. They did a good job with the last section of your visit. 

Customer service was great at the front desk. But in the gift shop where you buy your tickets I felt like the lady was irritated that I bothered her with a question."},{"author":"Katherine C.","datePublished":"2018-12-01","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"The introduction is excellent.  The initial film to the actual bus and the interactive film of her arrest is a treat to watch.  Its $7.50 for this half of history.  The artwork and artifacts are excellent.  There was free parking in the lot opposite corner of the museum.   Although the metered parking was plentiful and cheap.  Coins only though.  The museum took about an hour at a leisurely pace."},{"author":"Alexis B.","datePublished":"2018-04-30","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Great little museum on the site where Rosa parks was arrested for refusing to give her seat up to a white man on a city bus in 1955. There's a short video about segregation in busing in Montgomery and then a short video which depicts the way the arrest occurred. And then there are a couple of small rooms containing artifacts relating to her arrest and the subsequent successful Montgomery Bus Boycott, including the original fingerprint arrest record of Mrs. Park as well as other court documents and police records. (There is also a small gallery which, when I visited in April 2018, had some very powerful art by V. L. Cox.) The museum is a little on the small side, but well worth a visit if you want to learn more about Rosa Parks and the Montgomery Bus Boycott in the place where that history occurred!"},{"author":"Loren M.","datePublished":"2016-03-29","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"As an educator I jump at the chance to learn about historical events so while in town visiting family I knew I had to stop at the museum. 
My first impression was that the staff was not very warm or welcoming. The tone of the 4 people that I encountered was not very helpful or patient. 
Once we got our tickets we went to the Children's Museum which consisted of a big noisy "bus ride" that played a video that took the rider through history up until the Rosa Parks incident. I found this part very overwhelming even as an adult. 
Back at the museum we watched another short film and then went into a room to watch a video reenactment of the night Rosa Parks was arrested. 
The museum has other paintings, photos, memorabilia, and artifacts that take you through the civil rights movement. 
I would say this is a "must do" while in town."},{"author":"Michelle J.","datePublished":"2018-10-21","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Beautiful museum that honors a civil rights pioneer. The staff is amazing. I didn't have a lot of time but they have a gallery, in case you don't have time for the museum. There are two parts to the museum so you should leave about two hours. When I return I will probably take the time to really take it in. I didn't count on there being so much to see in Montgomery."},{"author":"Iman S.","datePublished":"2018-11-10","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Had a wonderful visit to the Rosa Parks Museum. I didn't realize that the children's wing and main museum were two separate things. This is probably why the first time we tried going, we thought it was closed but it said it was open. But it's because we were at the children's wing entrance. So be mindful of that. Just walk up the sidewalk and the Museum and Library entrance are right there. 

Decided to take my 7yr old, because it was the day of the midterm elections and she's doing a report on Rosa Parks for school. 

She said it Mae her feel a little creeped out. I asked her "why?", because we had also gone to the EJI's Lynching Memorial and she didn't find that disturbing at all. Apparently for her the photos and videos at the Museum make it more real for her. But she did retain a lot of the information about Rosa and the boycott. 

I'm going to ask if her school will take the kids to the children's wing next year. 

The staff is friendly and very helpful. Enjoyed ourselves"},{"author":"Jon C.","datePublished":"2015-11-16","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":""This is so creepy. Hurry up" is the text that I got from my friend while making a slight detour and hitting the restroom instead of walking into the "time machine" immediately after paying $28 for two adults do to both the Children's Time Machine piece as well as the museum.  

When I walked through the doors, I saw what he was talking about. Inside a big room sat an over-sized replica of a bus surrounded by used computer parts and lights that were intended to make the place look like you were traveling back in time. I don't know if I would have called it creepy - but with him being the only person in the room, I can see why he wanted me to hurry up and get there so they could start. That's right.. it was just the two of us along for the trip through time.

The feature started and Mr. Rivetts, our "bus driver" (which looked like the robot from the movie Short Circuit) took us on a trip through time starting in Cincinnati meeting a young boy named Jim Crow and ended up in the 1950's after being introduced to Mrs Parks. While definitely geared towards children, it was worthwhile to go through. There were TV's throughout the entire room and the walls became projection screens, so even if the room was packed with students on a field trip, everyone would be able to see.

After going through the Children's part, our admission also got us into the 1955 and beyond part of the exhibit. A much smaller room was waiting on us with very few seats, but we sat down and watched interviews on three projectors and learned more about Rosa Parks specifically. After about 15 minutes of watching this, the automatic doors opened and we were outside on a street corner in 1955 watching and listening on the city bus when Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat. 

The rest of the tour was a self-guided walking tour of the bus boycott, church meetings, police reports and historic memorabilia. As I walked through the museum, I thought to myself many times "I can't believe this happened only 50 years ago!" 

Learning about this in the history books is one thing.. walking the streets of Montgomery and seeing it unfold on a likelike tour is something completely different. I'll always remember this trip and be thankful that I was able to do it."},{"author":"Dee H.","datePublished":"2017-08-07","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Troy University oversees the Rosa Parks Library and Museum.  After a trip to the Civil Rights Museum, we stopped by here.  Without a doubt, the Rosa Parks tour features the most interactive and engaging setup that I have ever seen.  After passing the ticket gate, visitors are invited to watch an opening video on a three-panel television display mounted high above.  Given that we were a large group, seating was insufficient, but we didn't seem to take issue with plopping down on the floor.  In retrospect, it gave the video a drive-in sort of feel.

The next stop was an audiovisual tour of the Montgomery bus boycott.  A facsimile of the bus appeared against a wall.  Audio recordings simulated Ms. Park's refusal to vacate her seat; though Rosa's voice actor's speech was a bit slow, I appreciated the accompanying voices' authenticity until the moment of her arrest.  This part of the museum was very dark, so I would urge visitors to be careful navigating this space.  The doors opened to reveal a walking exhibit of the planning and aftermath of the bus boycott.  The guide continued to walk among the exhibits and ushered us through them.  When we got to the end of the walk, double doors featured an audio recording of a MLK sermon; at its end, visitors were invited to walk through them, simulating a church revival service.  The tour ended shortly thereafter.

I think the only thing I have to recommend is being told what else is in this building.  I suppose it worked out well since we had additional stops planned.  Nevertheless, I urge visitors to view other exhibits in the museum.  Of interest is a room showcasing the tattered clothing of enslaved Africans, their names tagged on the sleeves."},{"author":"Shara W.","datePublished":"2021-05-18","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Loved it he is interactive tours. Felt like i was there back in time. Very educational!"},{"author":"Shannon J.","datePublished":"2020-10-05","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"A beautifully crafted edifice in honor of our beloved she-roe-- Mrs. Parks that has a children's location right next to it!!!  Simply Lovely!!

Donaldsonville. La"}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":4.5,"reviewCount":66}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Saint James School","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/kFr3738R55ij36FafmtMRA/l.jpg","telephone":"(334) 277-8033","address":{"streetAddress":"6010 Vaughn Rd","addressLocality":"Montgomery","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"AL","postalCode":"36116"},"review":[{"author":"Robert W.","datePublished":"2022-02-06","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"My wife and I have been so pleased and felt blessed to be part of the Saint James family. 

Our Journey began in January 2021 when we made the decision to move to another public school. We traveled to  Birmingham and Auburn researching schools and neighborhoods. After a number of area visits, meetings with real estate agents and tours of homes, nothing seemed to fit.  So at one point  we looked upward and ask God, "this isn't working out, do you have other plans"?

He then began to unveil His plan. That was to look at private schools in the Montgomery area. The cost would be significant, however, after running the numbers, we realized the cost of moving coupled with the premium for housing, we would actually save money over five years. 

We began to reach out to private schools and narrowed our search to two. One a Christian school and the other, Saint James, a secular school. We then began communications with the admission office. 
They were amazing. Their processing of new applicants was as well orchestrated and professional as one could have imagined. 
Next came the course selection process. Once again, this team was very engaged in guiding us along as we chose the academic course levels and electives. 
 
During the open house event, we heard from the head of school, Dr. McLemore, and the middle school principal Dr. Taylor. They deftly handled the power outage that evening and carried on without the use of lights or PowerPoint. They didn't miss a beat. The handout materials they provided during that meeting were well thought out and very useful. 

Finally, after meeting with each of the teachers, we gained so much confidence that God had led us to the right school. We had scoured Birmingham and Auburn in our quest to find the right culture and environment best suited to prepare our son for college and life. As it turned out, that school was Saint James. 

Everyone we have met has been so helpful, communicative, responsive, and professional. Even the parking lot attendant is a great guy! 
The consistency, professionalism, courtesy, communications and passion to the education, emotional and psychological well being of our children has been such a constant theme throughout our Saint James experience. 

While we initially had some reservations over choosing a secular college preparatory school over a Christian school, as it turned out, Saint James is staffed with teachers and administrators who lives are marked by Christ. While Saint James doesn't have required Bible study or verses displayed on their marketing materials or on the school walls, it's clear the presence of the Holy Spirit is in this place."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":5,"reviewCount":1}}

For someone who works with children and special needs children at that, I find his use of language very offensive. TLE is exactly what my family needed with our busy work scheduled. 

Thank you so much for all the TLC you give Isabelle A."},{"author":"Sandra G.","datePublished":"2019-05-22","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Let's begin by this is the first time I leave a review about something ever!!! But I think this time is worth it. 

We love this day care!!!! Moving from NY to NJ without knowing anyone or the area was hard for the entire family and having to find a daycare for our 1 1/2 year old was even harder. It was his first time in daycare, so it was a big decision for all of us. We tried looking at the reviews but there weren't many and some were useless and ridiculous. We visited a couple of daycares in the area, but TLE Union was our favorite. We liked it since we set foot on it. The tour was very welcoming and the people were nice. The entire place was clean and organized. We all loved the decorations, even my baby, who stopped on every wall to contemplate the pictures and colors and he didn't want to leave. So we decided to enroll him in the Toddler class. His teachers were Agatha, Catherine, Melanie and Jasmin. We can't thank them enough for all the patience and care they had with our baby. He cried every single morning for the longest time, but no matter how much he cried, they welcomed him every morning with a smile, a big hug and love. Eventually he stopped crying and started asking in the morning if he was going to go to school that day, because he wanted to go!!! Also the front desk girls are amazing, specially Jessica, who had to take my multiple calls to check on my baby for the longest time until I had to learn not to call because he was fine. He moved to Twaddler class at the beginning of this year and he loves it! His teachers are Rebecca, Melanie and Wendy. They also are amazing and give him so much love and care. He is learning so much, counting numbers, days of the week, colors, months of the year, telling us stories, and all his classmates names. It's been a year now since he started and we are as happy as we were at the beginning. They make lots of activities during the day, each month they celebrate something different so lots of activities related to it, each week there's something fun for the kids like wacky hair day, pijama day, crazy socks day, battle of colors between classrooms, and many more. Food is good (snacks, lunch and afternoon snack), a party here and there with pizza and goodies, tuition is not cheap but not expensive, it is fair and after seeing the way they take care of our baby, we are happy to pay it. Halloween was awesome with the "trunk or treat" in the parking lot. Another amazing thing about it is the app where we get live updates of what our kid is doing, pictures of him during activities, lunch, nap time, daily reports and important notifications such as future activities, school's closures, etc. 

I hope this review gives you the help I didn't have when I was looking for daycare and gives the school an idea of how happy they make the parents because of their great work. It was hard to leave my baby to go to work and even harder and scary to have to leave him with strangers, but that feeling didn't last long because I realized the good hands I was leaving him with. Thank you TLE Union for all the help and love you have given us so far, and hopefully continue giving us for many more days."},{"author":"Cecilia D.","datePublished":"2018-12-12","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"We love the Learning Experience!!! Having had our daughter in daycare at a previous daycare for her first 8 months and then dealing with significant health issues for 6 months, scared was one of many words we could've used about starting our daughter in a new daycare once again. The Learning Experience provided everything that we needed and more in a daycare and has been there every step of the way for us. Our daughter has been able to flourish in more ways than we would've thought possible and that is directly due to the great care she receives at the Learning Experience. Not only us, but her various therapists who have visited the school, in-laws, and others have praised the quality care and concern the Learning Experience shows. Words cannot express how grateful we are and we would hands down recommend Learning Experience to any parent looking for a quality daycare."},{"author":"Alina M.","datePublished":"2016-09-08","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"Good day care but very disappointed how they handled my child's bitting issues and expelled us without notice. Very patient with the kids. My son learned  lot in a short period of time. I would recommend it to all."},{"author":"Kevin B.","datePublished":"2017-12-20","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"TLE Union has been a good day care for us. The teachers in preschool class do a good job of instilling responsibility and organization into the children.  Furthermore, all the classrooms in TLE seems to do a lot of crafts and art projects, which is fun for the children and really decorates the school.  As with any day care, there are times when there are issues that come up, but for me the core of any day care is about whether or not the teachers genuinely care about your children, and the teachers at TLE Union do."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":4.5,"reviewCount":9}}

Wadiah Lamadieu"},{"author":"Khyati R.","datePublished":"2017-03-27","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"I love going out to studios for paint and wine,  pottery,  wine glass paint night etc.  Usually groupon have pretty good deals. I'll be back for sure!"},{"author":"Madame W.","datePublished":"2015-07-17","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"I purchased the class off living social. We took the pottery class it was very interesting and fun.  The place is bright and welcoming. We meant some awesome people there. The instructor did try to delay the class for lil bit because of parking and traffic that was considerate of other clients. Con's ----Customer Service was 1-5 I will give the instructor a 3. We walked in and did not get a warm greeting and no instruction of wear to sit. Our time was running out we not instructed we have only few minutes please start finishing your project. If you think you going to pottery class and it's going to be like the ghost movie you are wrong. lol And your item is not getting painted that day because it will not be dry. There is not a oven there to speed up the process to dry the pottery. I think she said you have to wait 7 days for it to dry. We were given boxes to take our item home but it was not secure so be sure be careful on your ride to home. #Tip arrive early for parking. #And do not expect a reminder call or email for your reservation."},{"author":"Lissa M.","datePublished":"2010-10-23","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"I went to this place for their Cocktails & Canvas night  - you come in to make a painting and can bring your own beverages. The owner of the studio instructs you how to paint a picture that everyone is looking at. In the end you all end up with a painting that looks a lot like the picture.

If you are Pablo Picasso then this is probably not the place for you. You would not get too much from having someone giving you step by step instructions on how to paint; it would probably stifly your creativity. But if you are just a regular person who wants to do this for fun and have a reasonably good picture to hang on your wall, then try it out.

I do recommend bringing a friend, because I went by myself and everyone else there were in their own private conversation catching up with the friends they had brought. I had hoped for a better dynamic, which finally came towards the end, but bring a friend and try it. The campus is absolutely beautiful! The students that participated in the event were very helpful, nice and informative. They answered all of our questions and had the decency of keeping our outdoor experience to a minimum, considering the frigid weather. 

If you're interested in applying or having your kids apply, we found out some wonderful information. Honor students have priority for preferred housing, in the next 1-2 years they will open their SHU Medical School and they are comparable to ivy league schools but offer a more intimate learning experience. 

The campus is a great size; not too big and overwhelming but large enough so that you have some space to walk to/from here and there. 

SHU seems like a great alternative to ivies, especially since they offer merit-based discounts and you're just not ever going to get that with an ivy, unless (on paper) you're financially in need."},{"author":"Donna D.","datePublished":"2019-11-21","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"University has a great reputation.  I enjoyed the Graduate Program here for Masters in Healthcare Administration .  The professors were all top notch and I learned so much. I graduated with high honors and have only high praise for this university"},{"author":"Edward O.","datePublished":"2019-09-16","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"They mostly do good things. A bit heavy on fundraising. I also notice course offerings. Tuition is very high and I wonder if they cant economize a bit and do without. Also would like to hear more Conservative voices and less PC culture catering to noisy small number of Liberals."},{"author":"Josephine A.","datePublished":"2018-02-09","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"I did two years at seton hall university. I think I didn't appreciate the school until I transferred. Anyways, the campus life is alright. There were frat parties and school promoted activities, Rutgers and NJIT are also close by (driving distance), Hoboken is a short train ride away and so is manhattan! 
The staff was well educated. This school is definitely more challenging than others I've attended so keep that in mind. 
The dorms are kinda shitty need to be renovated. During my second year I lived In the apartments off campus that the school provided and that was much better.  They take fire safety very seriously which I guess is a good thing but those 1 am fire drills were not fun... the cafeteria food wasn't so bad! I have a better time at Seton Hall than queens college (where I dormed) or Adelphi which I commute to for grad school. 
It's expensive if you dorm which is my biggest complaint. For 20k a year you mine as well get your moneys worth and go to a school with an awesome social environment. This schools social aspects were mediocre."},{"author":"Cynthia D.","datePublished":"2019-01-06","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Wonderful school and professors. I highly recommended it.  I got my BS undergraduate degree there in Secondary Education and it was a spectacular program.  I am so well prepared that I can teach any child to learn.  The heart of Seton Hall is what makes it exceptional.  This gives the student the moral character to face any challenge life and career brings."},{"author":"John R.","datePublished":"2019-10-11","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I really enjoyed my time at Seton Hall..the campus is always beautiful in the winter when it's decorated and summer on the green is always great...it's a nice walk down to the train station and within south orange and I always found the professors to be helpful. I had many classes in the school of Business which was a nice building to work out of. My favorite spot was the sandwich spot. It really set me up for a career after college and I am grateful for that."},{"author":"Adam D.","datePublished":"2013-10-13","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This review only pertains to the John C. Whitehead School of Diplomacy and International Relations. What an excellent program. I went here for my Masters from 2008 to 2010 and enjoyed every one of my professors and classes. And no, I'm not just giving in 5 stars because I went here.

The professors were great mostly because of their backgrounds. For example, my international criminal law professors were international lawyers, my international human rights professor the former Pakistani Ambassador to the United Nations, etc. When I was there, the Dean was the former US Ambassador to Bosnia-Herzegovina.

I never had any problems dealing with the registrar or the accounting offices. Didn't have to worry about financial aid either, because I never received any for grad school! So administratively, Seton Hall seemed to be squared away. The career development people were also incredible and hooked me up with the job I currently have. Also, because Seton Hall doesn't provide housing for graduate students, I can't speak for campus life, dorms, etc.

The few downfalls to this program:
1) The location is not the greatest. South Orange has some good spots, but the area right around the campus can be shady.
2) Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School graduates are almost certainly to be your biggest job competitors once you graduate.
3) The program has only been around for 10-15 years so it probably hasn't earned the praise it deserves because it's so young, but I think it's off to a solid start."},{"author":"Sandra M.","datePublished":"2019-01-23","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Tried to enroll in the ROTC program. Worst secretary or receptionist named Angella Gladden!!! She is rude and disrespectful!! I asked questions and she would reply in a rude way no matter what. I called her by her full name Angella Gladden and she responded don't ever call me that, I am Ms. Gladden, not Angella Gladden, don't don't do it. I was in shock by the form she talked to me. It looks like to me that she hated her life at that point. It's not the first time I tried to contact her. I told her I did not want to report or complain about her, so if she can please stop being disrespectful but I guess she didn't care. She replied with "report me or complain, I can care less!" Along with questions with how are you going to afforded seton hall or how are you going to be a student and do rotc like I couldn't work around that schedule. Seton hall needs to think twice about having her work for the rotc building or office. She really discouraged me in enrolling in the ROTC.."},{"author":"Allison A.","datePublished":"2017-02-12","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"A beautiful campus!  My daughter is a freshman and it has been nothing short of a positive learning experience.  All her professors give excellent feedback and truly show care for the individual student.  A perfect fit for her."},{"author":"Marisa M.","datePublished":"2017-06-29","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"I miss seeing Father John everyday. I'd come back to see him. 

On a serious note. Seton Hall is a D1 school - so hit up those chances to see free sports. Don't forget basketball - $10 student tickets. Get involved in whatever interests you. You can take it seriously and still have fun! Seton Hall became my home. 

"Come home to the hall" is not just a saying. 

The food can get sucky after a while, watch out for meatless Friday's during Lent, and don't forget there is a theater in the university center behind the help desk! 

Overall, there were problems, but I really loved it there."},{"author":"chavo d.","datePublished":"2012-07-30","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"Seems like Seton Hall has cleaned up their act a bit since the previous review (held up at gun point? Well, it is near Elizabeth, NJ), my visits were mellow and in the daytime, so only time will tell.

Pros: Nice Campus Layout, Goofy Mascot, Solid Basketball program
Cons: Rank dorm rooms, look like a 1960's prison!"},{"author":"Tom J.","datePublished":"2015-01-03","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Great school! My son is a junior there, living in the dorms. My wife and I both went there and were married in the chapel. Good facilities, close proximity to NYC . South Orange is nice town, some issues with cretinism bs from Irvington and Newark coming to edge of campus at night."},{"author":"Louis B.","datePublished":"2016-05-08","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Both of my kids graduated from Seton Hall. It was a bit of a struggle for me paying for seven consecutive  years back to back.At the end of the day I was very lucky and proud that my daughter was able to graduate in three years. I want to share the experience she had with Seton Hall after she graduated.
She graduated with a PR major and was able to find a nice job by helping out cancer patients with a non profit organization. She wanted to give back to Seton Hall, she was able to offer internships to Seton Hall students. Both of my kids were invited back to Seton Hall by to share their working experience with other students. 
Recently she decided to get her Masters and of course being a Pirate the school of choice was Seton hall again. She applied and got excepted at the same time she applied for 19 scholarship that they offer. She recently got a letter from seton hall saying that she doesn't qualify for a single dollar.
Let's face it we are the minority's. She comes from a Italian American white family, I own my own home and I might be considered middle class these days.
I didn't graduate high school because I needed to work during my teens. I can tell you that most people would agree that I'm the minority's. The sad part is that any other race would of qualified.
So please tell me who is the minority!
The sad part is that other colleges offered to help.
Over the past few years we had 8 family and friends that send their kids to Seton Hall because we always promoted your school. I manage a automobile dealership and deal with 55 to 70 customer per day. I always promoted your school because of the Pirate basketball banners in my office, well guess what ! You're done. 
Please stop sending me and my kid letters seeking donations.
It's a sad story and I'm hoping that it doesn't happen to anyone else. Seven years of payments, eight other families and friends that came there, eight years of school recommendations and this is the thanks that a parent gets.
One upset parent.
Lou Bittone"},{"author":"Chelsea B.","datePublished":"2013-09-13","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Ok I went to Seton Hall for undergrad and now grad school. I wouldn't say the undergrad was 5 stars, but the grad school is 100%. The Classical Studies courses are by far the best with the best professors teaching them. I only wish Professor Lake was still there because I would continue to take his mythology classes forever and ever. Every professor in the Classics department always went out of their way to help me out.  I found the professors were generally understanding. My advice to students is to give yourself plenty of time to figure out any scheduling issues, etc. Sometimes you have to runaround the campus to get problems solved, but it's like that at most colleges. Professors and admin are generally understanding if you are nice and professional. Basketball games are super fun and there's a bus that takes you right from campus to the game at The Rock (Prudential Center, Newark). There's also a train station so it's super fun to go into the city or Hoboken.

Grad school is def. 5 stars. I have enjoyed all but 1 of my MPA classes. The professors are brilliant, so are the heads of the program. I've even enjoyed a bunch of the books we've read minus some of the boring text books. Graduate school is such a difference and I am so glad I decided to come back for my Nonprofit Management degree.

Update: They have done a TON of renovation, from academic buildings to the new and improved rec center/gym, and dorms.
...As for the school, they are in the process of doing a ton of renovating and I love the small, homey campus. It's nice. There are some robberies outside the gates, and you will be notified by the PIRATE ALERT system. I honestly enjoy those emails for some reason... most of them end up being false reports. Never understood that...

Go Pirates!"},{"author":"Shauna G.","datePublished":"2013-05-30","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Don't do it to yourself. They are too expensive for the quality they offer. You will have better luck at other schools. No one is ever there to help you. Their systems, workers, and campus is also extremely outdated and old."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":3.5,"reviewCount":23}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"St Johns Presbyterian Kindergarten","telephone":"(904) 389-8191","address":{"streetAddress":"4275 Herschel St","addressLocality":"Jacksonville","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"FL","postalCode":"32210"},"review":[{"author":"Anna J.","datePublished":"2019-02-09","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This is a great school. Every time I walk in the doors I am ushered into a happy and loving environment! They truly care about the children and showing Christ's love!"},{"author":"Abby S.","datePublished":"2019-01-11","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"All four of my children went through from MMO through preK.  They were exceptionally well prepared for Kindergarten and their teachers were fabulous!"},{"author":"Meridith A.","datePublished":"2015-10-27","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"I thought long and hard about posting this review, and I've waited a year to do so, but I really would have appreciated if I'd known this before I made a decision that so deeply affected my child.

This is based solely on my family's personal experience.

1.   SJKP offers curbside drop off and pick up.  If this is convenient for you, great.  If, however, you are like me and enjoy walking your child into his/her classroom and getting them settled before hugging and kissing them goodbye for the day, you will be discouraged from doing so.  Although I was told during my tour that "parents are always welcome in the classroom," I was asked by the teacher to say my goodbyes outside the door and not come in (this was also later formalized in a memo from the director to all parents).  When you pick up and drop off your child this way (in a rush at the curb with a line of other parents waiting), you get no feedback from your child's teacher(s) about his or her day and no real opportunity to communicate your own questions, concerns or comments.  I felt alienated and found it very dismaying and distressing.  

2. Nap time policy is that children do not have to sleep, but if they do not sleep, they are expected to rest quietly on their mats with no toys, books, or other distractions for approximately two hours (I don't know any adults that could do this with no phone, book, tv, etc, let alone a two-year-old).  My child is not a napper.  We struggled with this the whole time he was there.  If I didn't ask if he napped, no one told me.  They waited until it was so bad (he was yelling, kicking walls, and causing a major ruckus) to tell me on a Friday that he would not be welcome back for naptime starting Monday.  There is no alternative available to a non-napper.

3.  During summer session, they rotated teachers every couple of weeks so leadership was very inconsistent for my child.  They were loose on the "rules" so when the school session started in August, we had to overcome two and a half months of letting certain things go, then backtrack to reestablish what would be expected of him.

4. Because I was discouraged from entering the classroom, I had no idea who my child's classmates were, and I rarely had the chance to meet any other parents.  

5. This school's philosophy is very centered on obedience.  When a child is "disobedient," he/she is sent to the director's office.  My son told me once (and remember, this is a two year old!), that "Mrs. [director's name] was very angry to me."  I found this attitude to be very unrealistic for such young children, and that it limited creativity and independence.  

I removed my son from this facility after approximately four months."},{"author":"Kalle C.","datePublished":"2018-03-22","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"This school was recommended by another good school so I figured it would be ok. I went for a walk through & it appeared to be a nice looking school. I was told my daughter would be able to attend the school & they had plenty of room. The next couple weeks following about two weeks to be exact I completed the application and tried for a couple days to get in contact with someone. Which I find very odd that I called this school, their main phone number and always went to voicemail. I've never seen a school that doesn't answer their main phone literally throughout the whole day. I even emailed and still till this day no response. I finally got in contact with one woman and she gave me some excuse as to why the phones were never answered. I then told her i had filled out the application and was trying to give the enroll deposit. I was told the school was full.... weird that when I came just two weeks prior they said they had all the space available. Mind you I am a South American man of color & of course my child is also of color. Now I kind of see why they weren't an abundance of "minorities" in their school. Really trying not to judge, especially a school that's so of "God"."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":3,"reviewCount":4}}

Main complaint is that the library is supposed to be used for quiet studying. Being quiet is a rule of thumb for visitors to the library but is expected of the library's employees. 

Unfortunately this library isn't a good spot to study at though as there are two employees there who shamelessly flirt with each other just about every day. They laugh and bellow so loud that you can't focus on what you're doing even with earphones on. I'm glad they like each other and they have some kind of thing going on. Everyone who spends more than 20 min in the library when they're both working at the front desk knows of them. The issue lies in the common courtesy they don't extend to those who need to use their facilities to study/get things done. 

If it weren't for the constant chortling and loud laughter from the pair, this would be a great study space."},{"author":"Tara H.","datePublished":"2016-05-11","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"I came to do documents for my job at the assessment testing center. Overall the campus is a great size. I love how the classrooms are outdoors, they've got great seating outside to study or eat lunch. 

They even have a subway on campus. They've got 5 parking lots. Clean and nice campus."},{"author":"Tj G.","datePublished":"2015-12-07","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"Welcome to another T2 review where I give you the pros and cons of the business I'm rating. 

Ah, FSCJ.... FCCJ, what ever their name is now. I can say I applaud any true educator trying to enhance the lives of their students with knowledge. I won't get into politics, but until the reorganization is over I can't give a fair review. That being said, it's a bit crazy with the current re-org. Now for what you came for

PROS:
*Medical, culinary, cosmetology, and police schooling mostly done on this campus
*Spacious campus
*Art Gallery is a neat place to visit. Nothing fancy, but art is view of expression I enjoy
*Kind Admin staff all over. Shout out to the Student Success Center and Library staff!!!
*Idk about teachers so let's not go there. 
*Food at the cafeteria is delicious and cheap! Just the way I like it. With "economical" prices for healthy options as well. 
*Friendly security team. Super helpful too.
*Water front lake. Nice touch and cool to look at. It needs some work done, but overall pretty cool to look at. 

CONS:
*Not a lot of campus school spirit. Idk who to credit that too.
*Lack of school unity. Each campus has its own personality...as it should, but doesn't seem like the brand of FSCJ is incorporated...hard to explain, but you'll get it if you visit all the campuses.
*parking...just weirdly designed 

Overall I give FSCJ a solid 4 out of 5 stars. I haven't heard too many complaints about the quality of school...it's a community college where a lot of UNF teachers teach as well. I'll let you speculate on that. 

Thanks for reading and I'll catch you on another T2 Review! -Tj"},{"author":"Julie A.","datePublished":"2008-12-28","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"North Campus is a much smaller campus than South Campus. The focus of this campus is medical degrees, culinary arts, and cosmetology.

This campus is great because they offer very low priced dental cleaning. They even offer low priced hair salon and a fine-dining restaurant on campus. (Even the regular old cafeteria food here was superb!) This is a very important thing for us who are not blessed with health insurance, especially in these ridiculous economic times. The only draw back is that these services are only available for very limited hours (only on weekdays when most of us are working).

I went here for the radiography program, and my teachers were excellent. The program director was extremely helpful and personable and answered any questions I had about the program or the career."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":4,"reviewCount":4}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"a child's place Montessori School","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/RvhSDqoG0P5rSPOmWGHxsw/l.jpg","telephone":"(904) 733-5797","address":{"streetAddress":"3718 Salisbury Rd","addressLocality":"Jacksonville","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"FL","postalCode":"32216"},"review":[{"author":"James H.","datePublished":"2020-11-19","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Probably not for everyone, but our daughter hated the chaos of a typical daycare. A Child's Place has provided her a structured and safe learning environment where she is free to express her emotions. The staff has expectations of the parents which requires an adjustment period, but it is intended to provide the children consistency throughout their day. 

This school promotes a pacifist culture rather than an aggressive one. The curriculum leverages a student's interest to cultivate their natural abilities. For example, students interested in art can spend more time doing art while students more interested in math can focus on math. This allows the children to define themselves. Conflict resolution is also built into the culture and no staff member ever raises their voice at the children. 

The facilities do not have a commercial feel to them like most daycares. Operations are very transparent and not governed by corporate policy. COVID-19 created some hurdles but those were widespread. I can't imagine sending my child anywhere else."},{"author":"Ellie M.","datePublished":"2020-10-02","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Our child is in her fourth year at A Child's Place Montessori and she loves it. We are so happy with our decision to send her here!

The school environment is enriching, with a huge variety of learning and creative opportunities, and very true to the Montessori method. Our child has benefitted academically because she loves learning and loves going to school. All she wanted to do for her birthday was stay at school ALL day until they closed, and she once told me that Friday is her least favorite day because she doesn't have school the next day. We enjoy reviewing her weekly work log to get a glimpse at what she is currently working on and what her goals are, and the work she brings home is high quality.

The staff is supportive and accommodating. Any issue or concern we have had has been addressed and resolved quickly and to our satisfaction.  We enjoy the scheduled teacher conferences twice per school year, where we are able to discuss our child's progress and see her work. Outside of conferences, the teachers have made themselves available and accessible for any questions. During normal times, the school offered plenty of opportunity to volunteer in the classroom, and we have delighted in spending time helping -- I wish I could go to school here! 

If you are looking for a unique, nurturing environment for your child, we strongly recommend A Child's Place Montessori."},{"author":"Jenny L.","datePublished":"2020-05-18","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"My children attended ACP for 6 years. My daughter went from 4 months old to almost 6 and my son from 3 to 9 years old. This school is amazing and the staff is the best in Jacksonville. If you are looking for authentic Montessori you cannot get better than this school. My kids have been out of the school for 2 years now and we have yet to find a school that compares to ACP. I have insanely high standards for my children's education because of the amazing foundation they received here. They truly work on whole child development including independence/ self care, social/emotional, physical/nutritional, and academic. The school has a very low turnover rate in teachers which is a hard thing to find nowadays in schools."},{"author":"Patricia C.","datePublished":"2016-07-28","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"My son was in the infant room with Ms. Angela from 6 months old till he was just over a year old. We only left because we moved to California. After going to 2 other different AMI certified Montessori schools, I can attest that this place is the most legit Montessori school around. From a very young age at A Child's Place, my son learned to drink from a cup independently, use utensils, wash his hands, get dressed. He embraces exploration and loves the outdoors. The location we went to has a great outdoor area and is set in a home like setting. The staff are caring, patient, and very communicative. We wish A Child's Place existed in California!"}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":5,"reviewCount":4}}

NLU, under great pressure by the NCAA was forced to drop their long-time battle cry and change their name, to well, anything, just anything but Indians. So, they did change it to just anything: Warhawks. To this day, nobody knows what a Warhawk is. And then a few years after the mascot debacle, NLU became ULM: University of Louisiana Monroe. Thus further completing the complete alienation of all alumni, friends, and associates of the university up and to that point. It is a solid academic institution to this very day with a gorgeous campus now accentuated with new and remodeled buildings dedicated to learning and the acts, thereof. It also has a picturesque bayou and a perennial National Championship-contending men's and women's waterski team. They have many wonderful programs and avenues to study here and a long and bright future. They just have no history here. No. Not anymore."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":4,"reviewCount":3}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Calhoun Community College","telephone":"(256) 876-1000","address":{"streetAddress":"102 Wynn Dr NW","addressLocality":"Huntsville","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"AL","postalCode":"35805"},"review":[{"author":"Pamela M.","datePublished":"2021-07-14","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"I had a good experience at Calhoun back when. I attended Calhoun when they had satellite campuses all over the place. The main campus was (and I guess still is) in Decatur, and yes you had to attend a lot of classes there; however, they also had satellite classrooms on Redstone Arsenal, Huntsville High School and in "THE Mall" - yes where Barnes and Noble is now, only further down the mall - you had to hang a left at the western themed bar and it was on the east side of The Mall where Picadilly used to be. We always joked that if you leaned in closely enough to the cinder walls you could still hear the servers saying "Serve you, Serve you please?!?!?!" :D

Because high school was such a breeze for me and really did not prepare me for college, I started UAH with a whopping 1.0 and yes, academic probation my first semester. I had no idea you could drop a class and really did *not* think the professors meant what they said when they assigned voluminous amounts of reading/coursework with only a day or so to accomplish it, and I paid for it with terrible grades my first semester.

Enter Calhoun! Calhoun to the rescue! I took classes all over north Alabama or at least it felt like it with part time college professors and full time ones, too. Anyway, it was still hard work; however the staff were friendlier than UAH, more accommodating to those of us who worked, and had more of a smaller, diverse group of students. I still learned and I learned a LOT at Calhoun!

I managed to pull my grades up to graduate with two associates at cum laude and transfer back to UAH to do the same with 1 BA cum laude.

The tip for anyone planning to do a similar approach to getting a degree is to stay in touch with UAH and ensure each class and associated credit *will* transfer from Calhoun to UAH. To me, and I'm sure to any college student, these hours are pretty much worth gold and you don't want to lose them! Also, don't be afraid to take any issues where a credit is denied to the Dean (or higher if necessary) to argue your case. Pay attention to the handbooks (if that's a thing anymore) and ensure the classes align in terms of course content.

Oh, and another good thing about Calhoun is you don't rack up 1000s of parking tickets by attending there."},{"author":"Marisa G.","datePublished":"2014-09-27","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Don't use the vending machines...ever. You're better off going to the gas station next door."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":3,"reviewCount":2}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Leeds College Of Music","telephone":"0113 222 3400","address":{"streetAddress":"3 Quarry Hill","addressLocality":"Leeds","addressCountry":"GB","addressRegion":"XWY","postalCode":"LS2 7PD"},"review":[{"author":"Alexander D.","datePublished":"2013-10-24","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"I was impressed when seeing their amazing facilities, ensemble rooms, practice booths, etc. However, I have to say, I am really really extremely gutted when I started my course here. It was a huge disappointment. I decided to move to Leeds for the BA in Popular Music course at LCM, having come from a music college in London. First of all, offering no class in music theory and harmony is rather an odd thing for a specialist music institution. My first guitar workshop was held in the basement of a pub across the street?! And that workshop, for 1st year students, were to teach us how to recognise notes on the fretboards while they were expected to have at least grade 8 in their playing skill, but can't recognise what notes they're playing on the fretboard??!! I had 3 days of school per week, only 3 hours out of those 20, I get to use my guitar at school. For the first couple of weeks, the task for the weekly band practice session was just to come up with random riffs which the supervisors don't even care, and then go home without even remembering a bit of it. Tutors are inexperienced. One of the guys I had didn't seem to know much more than I do. 1-to-1 lessons are completely directionless with no specific curriculum. To make it short, I did not get what I expected, I did not get to learn any theory and harmony, I didn't get to improve my sight reading skill, I didn't get to practically learn to play the guitar, I didn't get to improve my aural & transcribing skills, etc. All you'd get there is endless boring lecture about different songs, how to analyse songs by listening to them, and how to successfully make money in the music industry, which the assignments are all about. Nothing is specifically designed for your chosen instrument except for the workshop and the 1-to-1 lesson which takes up no more than 15% of the hours each week.  

So I ended up quitting within the first 3 weeks. I have heard disturbing rumours that they had seriously dire money problems, and I could clearly see for myself, upon enrolment, that they had certain policies that are set up to rip students off. It's a common thing for universities in the UK to charge non-EU students a higher tuition fee than that EU students have to pay. So when filling out my personal details on the enrolment form, I told them that I was holding dual citizenship, and then they insisted on the fact that I have to pay higher tuition fee because one of the citizenships I was holding is non-EU, despite the fact that I do have British citizenship and grew up here. I ended up having to pay almost two grants more than the EU fee. And for my case, being considered an "international student", the school had a policy for such students that they are required to pay 75% of one-year tuition fee before enrolment and there would be a no-refund policy applied if they decided to withdraw. With that no-refund policy, they obviously want to rip you off by demanding that much money before enrolling you just to make sure they could still keep a large amount of money and wouldn't lose a lot if you decided to withdraw. I was so determined and certain that it was definitely the right uni for me, so I decided to pay the fee in full upon enrolment instead of just 75% as required. 

So they wouldn't give me a refund for those stupid reasons. They made that decision of not giving me a refund a couple of days after I handed in the withdrawal form. I was so angry and frustrated. I thought I had no choice but have to continue with the course, so I asked them to disregard the withdrawal request but then they said they'd just enroll someone on their waiting list so they had no more space for me to come back then, wtf??!!!

At the end, I tried to negotiate and only managed to get back 50% of what I'd paid, and they called that "a gesture of goodwill"??!! What really pissed me off was that the head of school even said to me that it was a very "unfortunate" thing that I paid the full tuition fee upon enrolment while I was only required to pay 75% so that's why I would lose the entire amount. So does that mean THEY are the ones who're in the "fortunate" situation?! Yeah, that's right, I lost over 5000 pounds to them for nothing!! 

Their money problem can be easily seen by looking at the way they try to cramp too many students in this school. All the seminar-type classes I was in never had enough chairs.

Again, to make it short, I would not recommend this school at all, absolutely not!! I can't speak for the entire school, but at least for the BA course in Popular Music, just don't!!! It's completely crap, just stay home and spend about 1 to 2 hours of practice by yourself every day then after 3 years you'd be way more better than those graduates from LCM. And I mean it, I seriously mean it, it's not an exaggeration. If you go there for 3 years, all you'd get will be a shoddy degree with a trashy piece of paper that says you can play an instrument, and that you mainly do classical/jazz/or pop"},{"author":"Qype User (mimin…)","datePublished":"2009-01-17","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":4},"description":"I took a couple of part-time guitar instruction classes at Leeds College of Music a while back. The teaching was of a high standard, well organised and requiring good attendance and quite a lot of homework on the part of the pupils. The teacher was pretty demanding and would pull us up if we clearly hadn't done the required work - which I think is a good thing!


 To be honest I didn't make the progress I would have liked with the classes, but that was entirely my fault. If I'd done all the work I needed to put in, then I would have got a lot better than I did. The teaching itself was not the problem - it was excellent, and in a rather attractive building with good facilities too."},{"author":"Jade C.","datePublished":"2012-10-18","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This place is like heaven for techies and instrumentalists alike, with countless practise rooms and a recently installed £250,000 mixing desk in one of the studios. The lecturers really know what they're talking about, and the students are really friendly. The only bad thing is that the in house bar/restaurant stop serving breakfast at 11am!"}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":3.5,"reviewCount":3}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Joda Collins Driving Academy","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5w-sO69cevfboQNZ21EbEw/l.jpg","telephone":"(850) 981-3355","address":{"streetAddress":"","addressLocality":"Milton","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"FL","postalCode":"32583"},"review":[{"author":"Shane N.","datePublished":"2022-11-16","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Joda Collins Driving Academy worked out great for me. Everything was kept simple and prompt by using email. this Academy also had spots available to wear. I did not have to wait long. Mr. Collins was on time without any aggravation, and his instructions were simple and easy to follow. As a teacher, his emotions never changed nor did his answer. He will teach you the exact way the state laws want you to drive, and he will also show you if you have trouble. Mr. Collins has a lot of patience and good communication skills for the business. He specializes in helping you get rid of your bad habits that we all accumulate over the years of driving. He helped me out tremendously. Thank you Mr. Collins."},{"author":"Dead B.","datePublished":"2021-11-05","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Great driving experience with Mr.Joda Collins.Be open mindsyou are needing these services because you are a bad driver.Be open and honest with your self.Very straight forward human."},{"author":"Erica K.","datePublished":"2018-09-07","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"Incredibly rude and unprofessional. Contracts posted online were unclear and inconsistent with what he says on the phone and in person. 

When we arrived early (meeting location: Circle K at 3804 Garcon Pt Rd Milton, FL) to speak about the terms of the contract (he even says in the preliminary email to set aside 1hr 45min to allow time for meet and greet when the lesson itself is 70min), he refused to answer questions about the prices and claimed we were on the clock starting from the second we met. We were wasting our lesson time, he said. He then compared our meeting to a ride on Disneyland while patronizingly refuting he wouldn't "argue with a teenager" when I attempted to clarify the contract. The concerning rebates/discounts did not match what he was telling us verbally. He began to pack up his belongings without warning and then threatened to leave if we wouldn't stop asking questions. I, baffled, repeated, "The online contract is unclear." He stood up and just left. Just like that. 

To be clear, online agreement says each lesson will be $125-$145 per lesson. This includes a discount for 10% if payment is not electronic (Visa, Mastercard, etc). Additionally, there is 18$ worth of discounts for three lessons. The discounts are as follows.

In section 2.2 of the agreement, it is stated: "A price reduction of four dollars ($3) per lesson ($9 total) for scheduling three WEEKDAY lessons (lesson one and two more) by 7pm the night prior to lesson two and prepaying all three WEEKDAY lessons not later than the start of lesson two." And section 3A reads: "Prepay for three scheduled lessons, do not miss any and receive a $9 rebate at the start of lesson three." 

When he only mentioned the rebate and the 10% reduction, I attempted to bring up the other $9 discount. This is when he began to get upset and attempted to deflect by saying we were wasting our lesson time. 

Keep in mind he charges $155 (without discounts) for 70 minute lessons. Compare to lessons in more populated cities where they will charge $300 for FIVE (5) 90 minute behind-the-wheel driving lessons. 

I had come with my mother and we both left in horrified awe, astounded by the lack of professionalism and lack of basic manners. 

Save yourself the trouble and do not waste your time. Definitely DO NOT waste your money."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":3.5,"reviewCount":3}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"College Nannies & Tutors","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5xTM7jzzq4ae1aprJjm9Wg/l.jpg","telephone":"(973) 629-3668","address":{"streetAddress":"","addressLocality":"Livingston","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"NJ","postalCode":"07039"},"review":[{"author":"Lissa J.","datePublished":"2018-09-11","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":1},"description":"The national average rate for nannies is a little over $14 per hour. In high cost of living areas, such as the NY Metropolitan area (including Northern NJ), the average salary for nannies is increased. 

College Nannies and Tutors thinks that it is acceptable to pay experienced caregivers $12-13/hour or less. This is below the national average and about equal to what caregiver working in a daycare center or even someone working a retail job might expect. 

When I explained that my rates start at $15-17 per hour for private childcare and increase for each additional child, I was rejected. College Nannies and Tutors does not feel that its employees deserve to be paid an appropriate, livable wage. 

I urge parents to take caution. Remember that, in many cases, you get what you pay for. Childcare is no exception."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":1,"reviewCount":1}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Educational Resource Center","telephone":"(973) 535-6585","address":{"streetAddress":"160 S Livingston Ave","addressLocality":"Livingston","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"NJ","postalCode":"07039"},"review":[{"author":"Jeanne S.","datePublished":"2016-10-10","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This is the best tutoring/ coaching/ testing/  center that exists for kids with any learning issues. Your children can be as young as kindergarten, but they teach thru 12th grade, and they teach college students as well. They teach students to prepare for the ACT/ SAT exams, as well as any other private school entrance exam. 

They help students who are struggling at school and they have on staff the learning specialists and psychologists who can do in depth testing to tease out the specific learning disabilities. Once you know what the issue is then thy help you address it.

Both of my sons went through the college prep courses and specialized coaching services to find the right college for them. Both of my sons were tutored in different subjects during high school.  Both of my sons have also utilized their services while taking a difficult college course. 

I love the staff and the owner, Laurie Levy. She cares about every student who walks in the door, and she personally evaluates the students to determine their needs.

Laurie and her staff also work with parents, helping them to understand how their child learns differently, and that is ok! 

I lived in Chatham and went to her Livingston office for years. I have also recommended them to friends. It is very rare, to find a gem of a company, that is owner operated, for 25 years, and many of her staff have been with her for that long as well.

If you suspect or already know that your child has any type of special needs or learning differences, just call for a consultation. Educating a child that has learning issues can really be difficult and the niche of Laurie's business is unique in the field of special education. My sons would not be the young men they are without the help and love from all of the staff at Educational Resource Center."}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":5,"reviewCount":1}}

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Great Swamp Outdoor Education Center","image":"https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/wAXKm5mOy9Zw2gwQtXUc1A/l.jpg","telephone":"(973) 635-6629","address":{"streetAddress":"247 Southern Blvd","addressLocality":"Chatham","addressCountry":"US","addressRegion":"NJ","postalCode":"07928"},"review":[{"author":"Anton K.","datePublished":"2019-02-15","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"The GSOE is a 44 acre dedicated National Wildlife Refuge located at the eastern end of the Great Swamp. The 2 miles of trails are predominately flat trails with wooden boardwalks across water features. The predominate features is swamp and marsh lands with forest habitat and ponds. Wildlife and horticulture abound with the rare sighting of threatened and endangered species. Check the sightings board for recent sightings. Self-guided trail maps and booklets are available. Digital trail maps are online at their website. Maps can be obtained in the kiosk outside the Visitor Center, as well as, inside the Visitor Center.

The Visitor Center should be your first stop. There are interactive educational exhibits which inform and entertain you about the natural history of the area. Taxidermy abounds along with interactive boards like Mammals of the Great Swamp and Speed of Animals which test your knowledge. They have bulletin boards all about on topics like Winter Wildlife and Match the Scat. A large sandbox can be used to make tracks in the sand of various animals. Lots of natural artifacts allow you to feel the fur of a multitude of animals.

They have a special events calendar online at morrisparks.net. Winter features Maple Sugaring   while Fall has the Lenape Day. A large reconstruction of a Lenape Wigwam is in the back of the Visitor Center.
The Visitor Center is open 9-4:30 pm on weekdays and is closed most weekends in the summer after June 23."},{"author":"Mindy S.","datePublished":"2016-01-13","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"This place is wonderful! The Outdoor Education Center has awesome programs all year 'round - hikes, summer camps, programs for birthday parties, scouts, schools... On weekends, there are seasonal public programs such as Apple Cidering in the fall, Maple Sugaring in winter, and Guided Walks any time of year. Check out their calendar on the MCPC website: www.morrisparks.net 
The trails are easy, but they wind through forest, marsh, swamp and past a serene pond that often has basking painted turtles, snapping turtles, bull frogs, ducks and the occasional great blue heron. I've seen wild turkeys, woodpeckers, chipmunks, red foxes, box turtles and red tailed hawks on my various trips to the GSOEC. It's well worth it, if for one of their programs, or to just walk along the quiet, beautiful trails."},{"author":"John K.","datePublished":"2014-04-13","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"This is another snippet of the Great Swamp cut off from the main part which is a part of the national park system. This tends to be a good place to see snapping turtles and painted turtles.Saw a fox here once , quite close up .This is a Morris County park ."},{"author":"Suzanna D.","datePublished":"2018-01-25","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":5},"description":"Went there on Sunday with my daughter, son-in-law and grandson. There for the maple syrup presentation. It was wonderful. The young woman who gave the talk was poised, pleasant--not stopped by all the children having fun throughout the room. Learned a great deal about the history and making of maple syrup. Then we went outside and watched a demonstration. Again, interesting and well presented by a man who really knew did a great job. Then inside again to do a taste testing! I could see that it is a perfect site for all sorts of nature adventures. Loved it as did my family. I certainly recommend it for family outings for everyone, from toddlers to seniors!"},{"author":"D E.","datePublished":"2012-07-07","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"This is more of a review for the Great Swamp itself, rather than the education center.  If you look at this swamp on a map, it is absolutely massive.  My wife and I have been up here a couple of times as they have a couple of nice hiking trails.  It isn't a massive or intense hike, but it's enough to feel like you did something and there are some decent sights along the way.  

On our most recent visit, we saw a ton of turtles which was kind of cool.  It can get a little buggy throughout, so you need to be prepared.  It's a nice place and I find it very relaxing.  I am sure that we will be back."},{"author":"Jeanelle A.","datePublished":"2009-08-15","reviewRating":{"ratingValue":3},"description":"Went there as a little kid with my girl scout troop one night and thought it was incredible, went there again this year with my boyfriend to realize it's buggy, small, and the extent of wildlife I'd the occasional turtle. There are only a few short trails which all are under 3 miles and are in circles.
